number of helpful: 17 of 31 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												The most expensive free game ever.Once you download all 3.5GB of this game, you are immediately presented with text telling you how awesome this game is (?) and then you are asked to purchase minimum of one (1.) pinball table for a small sum of 5 euroes. Of course, you can get a package that saves you TON OF MONEY, by paying about 25 euroes and receiving 10 tables.If you do not pay, you can play effectively for about 5 minutes of time since there is a highscore cap you can reach before the game boots you out, but hey, you are able to repeat this countless of times!You cannot save your highscore since you haven't payed, but there is one (1.) free table you can play.There are aparently some other free tables, which you have to find in the sea of pay to play ones, but I managed it. After I found one free table, it also asked me to purchase it. Bug or feature, I have no idea.The game itself is not that bad, graphics and gameplay are both decent. Camera is a bit tricky on some tables because it automatically follows the ball to certain edge of the table, making it really awkward to use the flippers as the ball comes back. Controls are quite simple and easy to use, although they are not what I would assume them to be.Overall:If you are not a pinball fanatic who has mountains of cash to burn, I recommend avoiding this game.EDIT1 - For the developers:The game is pretty bad with its current system, however, it has potential. Here are some of things I believe should be done in order to sell the game better and make it more successful:1. Remove the message on start up. No one likes a self brag.2. Cut the game and sell it. The game doesn't really need 3.5GB to operate, when a person that downloads it uses only 1 table. Also, why is this game free? It obviously is made with the intention to sell and that is alright. Put the price on the game, 5eur. Comes with 5 tables, Nothing else. Make DLC's containing 10 tables each that would upgrade to the game and sell them at whatever price you wish.3. Release a Demo. Allow players to download a free demo, containing only 1 free table - how it comes now.4. Do not bug the players to purchase ingame. It is offsetting. A simple "For more tables check out our DLC packages on Steam!" would do.5. Once all of the above has been done, promote. Give out a few cheap/free copies via bundles for example.Good luck.

number of helpful: 26 of 49 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Sorry for the lack of focus of the review, just writing this up as I go.Pinball has always been part of our gaming culture. It's technically the grandfather of all modern video games, mechanical pinball was the first arcade game. They've been around longer then any video arcade game. They're an important part of not just gaming culture, but the entertainment industry, right up there with any other fine art. And if you think about it, the amazing effort put into every specific machine is extraordinary. Just imagine putting all those little gears and lights and gizmos together, so someone can slap some flippers around to get a high score.Anyways, enough about my praise of the pinball machine and onto the review. Farsight has done an excellent job recreating over 40 pinball tables (to date) and releasing them in virtual form. There has been other attempts at true 3d virtual pinball recreations, mostly those PS2 games, but the amount of tables to choose from was small, and the graphics, quite poor. They were poor representations of the tables. Now, why should the casual game be interested in this? Because simply put, the pinball experience is something unique to it. If you have not already tried a pinball table before, a *REAL* one, not something like Pinball FX, then you should defintely download the demo and try out the free table of the week. It's a real treat to see everything about the IRL machine recreated in minute detail. The lights the ramps the targets the animitronics, the dialogue, the dot matrix displays, and the charm of even the older mechanical machines are all recreated virtually.Like I've said, you've got over 40 tables to choose from, with another 20 tables planned for release in 2014. Let me go over how the game isn't really free to play, but more like an actual paid game. You can buy individual tables for 4.99 each. Some of the tables are surely worth it, you've got legendary classics like Medieval Madness, Terminator 2, and quirky and rare tables like Cactus Canyon, and Going Nuts. You've got tables from all eras, old electro mechanical pins like Genie, and some of the more early released 1980s efforts by Balley like Black Knight and Class of 1812, both of which I highly reccomend, picking them up via the season 1 pack. The season packs cost 29.99 and come with 20 tables each. You're only paying for a few dollars per table, but if you want you can pick up individual tables of the more popular ones like T2 and Medieval Madness for 5 dollars each. I do not reccomend picking up the Pro pack, for 2 extra dollars you get a small change to the ini file and the option to access to the operator menu. Which also invalidates your score.Comparsions to Pinball FX2 can and will be made. Pinball FX is notably cheaper.. you can get Humble Bundle keys which contain 2/3 of the tables for a dollar. But a majority of the tables are Marvel liscenced virtual pins made only for the game. And a lot of them don't have very fun goals. Take a look at Farsights virtual repesentation of Funhouse on Pinball Arcade, which came out in 1990, side by side with Zen Studio's newest lisceneced table from Marvel, Dr. Strange and you'll see the difference. Funhouse is 20 years older and 20 times more fun. This is because the table's featured in Pinball Arcade are much better designed, have more satisfying rewards, and have a snappier pace.Virtual pinball in itself is a niche, but a niche defintely worth trying out. It's actually quite accessable, unlike most games that are niche - rougelikes for example. I would reccomend anyone with a passing interest to try out the game (Dont think its free to play, its defintely not, but they provide one fully functional table every month.) If you've played a pinball machine in your life, and you enjoyed it, download this game and give it a try.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												First, let me get this out of the way: NOTHING, EVER, in the computer gaming world will EVER be exactly like a real life analog pinball machine. There is no way to 100% digitize the analog workings of pinball games, EVER.With that said, this game gives us a very good digital representation of the real life tables. It's not perfect, but it's very close. It's close enough that I don't even notice the difference. There are probably some minor glitches but I haven't personally noticed them. The tables can be expensive though, at $5 per table, or buy the table packs to save some money. You DO, however, get a free table, which to me is still one of my favorite tables to play: The Tales of the Arabian Nights. The tables are a little pricey to purchase, but I understand there are licensing fees I'm sure they're paying, plus the work that goes into each individual table, so I don't complain THAT much about it.One thing I do like is, before you buy a table, you can play any of the tables you like for free, to see if you will even like that table or not. You just can't play for a high score, but you can see if you will even like the table so you don't have to buy the table blindly. Another thing that's great here is that for each table, there is a menu option that explains in detail how that particular machine works, what the objectives are, and how to score maximum points on it. It helps to know what you are trying to do on each table, and they outline each objective very well.I do wish the interface while selecting a table was a little bit better, but it's a minor complaint, as I don't play this game for the interface. All in all, I definitely like this one, and suggest you give it a try. It's great to play some of my favorite real life tables: Whirlwind, Tales of the Arabian Nights, The Addams Family, Star Trek, etc and have it look and feel a lot like the real thing. I feel like they spent a lot of time on each table to get it to act just like the real life analog tables, or as close as possible. Just be prepared to spend some money if you want to have a high score on your favorite tables.

												Single-handedly reinvigorated my love of pinball.  I used to play a whole bunch of these tables when arcades were still a thing.  Yes, I'm old.  Shut up. I know some people complain that it's not the same thing, and I agree.  It's never going to be an exact 100% recreation.  It's never going to be like plunking a quarter into Whirlwind. content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												First, I want to address the things that other people have issues with. First of all, I quite like the new UI update, not just because of how it looks, but also because TPA has so many tables now, and on the old UI, it took forever to scroll through them. The new UI streamlines things a bit, letting you choose your table from a huge grid, and tends to be more responsive than the old UI did. My only real gripe with the new UI is that it's also a little bit glitchy, especially when you use a controller. This is most notable when you're entering high scores - you can choose your letter alright, but you gotta click it with your mouse to enter it, since the button fails to enter it now. And this is the sort of game that I would prefer to use a controller for anyway, hence why I still play this game on my PS4 a lot, but that has the old UI still, making navigating very troublesome for me. Patch please!The other big issue that other people have with this is cost. A lot of people complain about how expensive the tables are. True enough, but these same people don't even seem to spare a thought for the programmers who went through the solid efforts to bring those tables to us. It must have been so hard for them to do all the research, and give you EVERYTHING the table had in real life. To say nothing of the painstaking physics engine that the game had from the ground up, which they gave to us for free, I might add. Considering all this, I strongly believe the prices are reasonable.In closing, TPA, while superb in its simulations, still doesn't quite beat playing a real pinny, and given how video game programming can only go so far (at least for now), that is unlikely to change. However, I would strongly recommend TPA because they are still the best simulations of real-life pinnies you could ever ask for.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												To put it simply, this game is *the* game to own if you like pinball.For a start, there are more than 50 tables (and counting) available, with one - Tales of the Arabian Nights - free to start you off. The tables are hugely varied and are sure to include something that appeals. A generous demo system means you can try tables before you buy and solid DLC systems mean you can buy the ones you like either in basic sets or "season packs".The physics are as good as anyone has ever managed for pinball on PC. For such a complicated (and on-going) emulation, the bugs are relatively few and far between - there certainly are some, but the game is updated regularly and the tech support team seem friendly and quick to respond to issues.Regular tournaments, table releases and ongoing leaderboards mean there is plenty to keep you coming back, and while not all the tables are solid gold classics, many of the best tables from the history of pinball can be found here from EMs like Central Park and Big Shot to later, deluxe tables like Attack from Mars and The Twilight Zone.This game gets a warm reccomendation and, if you like pinball - especially real life pinball - then it's simply an essential purchase.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												HOLY. COW.I've always enjoyed pinball games. Unfortunately, given the fact I live in a very rural area I've always had to make do with video game pinball tables, only having played real physical units a time or three. Despite that the history and design of the real tables have always fascinated me, and I've longed for a way I could experience some of the real classics.Well, here's the answer.In terms of production values as a video game Pinball Arcade is a little lacking in some areas. Overall visual fidelity isn't the greatest given the simplicity of its subject matter, and in all honesty the presentation of the game's menus isn't the most user friendly, with a strangely syrupy-feeling lag between menu selection inputs and their taking effect on-screen. In-game, though, things are completely different, with tight controls and a solidly reliable camera that makes actually playing the tables themselves a joy. Perhaps its simply my inexperience, but the physics of the tables do, at times, feel a bit on the floaty side, however.What really takes the cake in the game's presentation, at least for me, are the snippets of table background available when you launch each table. For players just looking to play some pinball these might seem like a bit of an annoyance, but for those who appreciate the history of the industry, or the history of games in general, these blurbs are fascinating and offer insight into the development of pinball games as a whole.The visual issues and physics mentioned above are nitpicky issues, but part of what makes them stand out is the price of the overall package. At thirty dollars or more a pop for each "season," or five dollars a piece to buy tables individually, the tables in Pinball Arcade feel like they come at a stomach-churning premium, especially when compared to its competitors. Doubtless the premium is partially due to licensing costs for the various tables from their original producers, but when alternatives like Pinball FX offer cheaper tables with arguably (from a video game perspective) more complex gameplay and higher production values, it can be hard to justify to oneself the pricing here. That said, there's something to be said for featuring "real" tables as opposed to completely unrealistic fantasy models, and when the content of each season is taken into account the price discrepancy isn't as great as it at first seems, since each season consists of 10 or more unique tables, meaning tables average out to about 3 dollars a pop if the basic version of each season is purchased, less for the Season 1 tables since there are 14 of them.If you're a pinball aficionado, Pinball Arcade is definitely the game to look at, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates more about game design than just the latest graphics engine and online shooting. The tables play nicely, and the extras make for a unique, well-valued package. If, on the other hand, you're turned off by the idea of solid-state hardware and often incredibly dated table aesthetics, then look elsewhere.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												I was very impressed with this title. The recreation of some of the more popular and fondly remembered pinball machines is very accurately done. Every sound, graphic and animation you remember has been faithfully reproduced.In short, it's everything you want a pinball game to be!Now for the negative; The menu graphics and fonts are large and clunky, and in general not very visually appealing, and changing graphic settings can only be done outside of the game, but both of these aspects can be largely ignored.The main downfall of this game is however, is pricing. While, for a pinball game, it hits all of the right sweet spots, to be able to play more than just one table, you need to spend a heck of a lot.To buy Season One (to essentially convert your "Demo" into a full game), it costs almost twice the price of Skyrim! Which is just not on.Do I recommend this title? Everything in me wants so desperately to say yes, as it's probably one of the nicest pinball games I've had the pleasure of playing, but I'm afraid this gets a no from me. Simply for the fact that I can't justify the pricing. I would have loved to play more of it otherwise.I'll be happy to change this review and recommend this title if the pricing is ever fixed. But until then, steer clear.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												My biggest issue is the price of the tables. I think the "first two seasons" have the best value because it gets you the most tables per cost, but the later seasons where you get 10 tables for 30 dollars is pretty steep for a game like this. That being said, I do like the mechanics, it is most "true to life" pinball available IMO. However, the biggest issue I run into actually playing the tables is their is little to no "inperfections" on the board. So balls will always "roll" perfectly and smoothly across. Which makes the game good and bad. Bad in a sense, that when you play the same table IRL and then on the game you could have a wildly different experience, but good, in that you can get a lot of practice on tables and know how you should approach games when you play them in tournaments or at the arcades. I know some people don't like the UI. I can relate, but to me it's fine. The historical low on DLC has been 14.99 a pack, two months ago they were on sale for around 20 a pack. Which is where I think the price of these should be. I would wait for a sale and get a "Season or two" of Pinball arcade and it gets a lot funner IMO. I personally wouldn't waste time getting the pro tables unless you really need options like turning off Extra ball (like they do in pro pinball events.) Otherwise you'll just want to play the games "stock." Overall, I do recommend this game. It's the only option on the market that has real life pinball table emulated as well as they could be.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Though I'm ultimately recommending the game, I'll start with the bad: It's buggy as hell. I've had the camera get locked in to an odd position that obstructed my view of the ball once, I have had several crashes due to alt-tabbing (please manage your memory better, devs), and two instances in which it froze before my game was complete. Oh, and as everyone else mentions, the UI is atrocious. To circumvent another bug, if you're accidently selecting a different game than what you've clicked your cursor on, then move the arrow buttons to move the dumb little blue selector box to the game you want. I get the feeling that many of these bugs are due to the fact that this is a pretty low quality pc port, and that the primary focus is on consoles. A pity.But the good far outweighs these issues: the tables are fun to play, accurate to their real life counterparts, and the ball physics feel great. It's nice to practice on specific tables so that I do better when I head down to the pinball arcade by my work.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												......after reading some of the negative reviews about this game, I would like to say that growing up in an era both before and through the videogame era, I spent thousands of hours playing Pinball in the smoke filled, dark and LOUD  Surfers Paradise "Pinball Alleys". This was even before Grundy's existed and I can surely say this game will take you back to that time and era of misspent hours. These games are EXACTLY the same as the machines back then. You even get to play from the simple 'rollover digit' machines, through the 'LED digit' era all the way to the 'all the ramps, video screen minigame, multiball era. I can say I have played all but a handful of these machines in real life, so if you want a game that will give you that "take you back" feeling and you are as old as I am, then this is a game for you...... even despite any small nuances..............

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												I've played on a lot of purely software pinball games over the years and they cannot hold a light to the original arcade machines. They are either too bland or just don't 'feel' like a proper pinball and lack depth of goals and features. With 'Pinball Arcade' we have those original arcade machines realised in full detail to take you back to, or introduce you to, those great original full featured tables that used to be in every Arcade all over the world.Over the past few years the developers have recreated an impressive catalogue of classic machines and the choice is vast. If you were into pinballs at all you are bound to find a few favourites in here to take you back.The physics are excellent, the sound of each table is utterly authentic and the tables have nice crisp graphics.This is THE pinball sim for anyone seeking out an authentic pinball experience.I also have this on my ipad mini 2 and thats the version I play the most...

												This is a good game for those pinheads who simply want tom play the Pinball games they remember.  HOWEVER do not expect the pinball physics to be the same.  For example Theater of Magic feels like you are playing pinball on the moon.  Ball just foats and bounces around everywhere.  As far as the feel of the machines NOPE.  The only to get that is too find a local arcade and play the actual tables.  This hits the "close enough" mark to be playable.  Although thru alot of frustration as the ball seems to have a life of it's own.Only reaon for recommending this is it's the only option around for playing a recreation of the actual tables in video game format.As for "Do you recommend this game?", it's a 50/50 split and depends on how frustrating the game has been that day.PLEASE fix the damn ball physics already!!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												If you're looking for pinball, look no further. Pinball Arcade is THE piball game to play. The selection of tables is like a hall of fame of pinball from classics like Pin Bot and my personal favorite, Xenon, to more modern choices such as Star Trek TNG or Adams family and Indiana Jones. All of the tables have been carefully crafted to look and play like their real life counter-parts. From the sounds all the way up to the original LED animations, this is as close to the real thing as it gets. The game is free to download comes with Tales of the Arabian Nights for free but all the other tables will cost you. The prices for individual tables do seem a bit steep. However, if you're a big fan of one particular machine, and only really want to play that one, they can be purchased individually and I feel the price for what you get is pretty fair. The tables can be purchased in bundles at a small discount as well if you need to have it all. I for one enjoy the a la carte style. This is worth it just for the free to play Tales of Arabian Nights, but if you're anything like me, you'll soon want to own your favorites as well.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I've probably played every Pinball game in existence on various systems but to me "The Pinball Arcade" is easily the best of them all. No need for Gimmics or Special FX it's as close as you can get without playing the actual Pinball table. Although come to think of it sometimes it's better because there's no dodgy flipper or bad reflections as many Arcades place the tables (in the UK at least) too close to a window.The DX11 version is the Mutts Nutts (or DB if you prefer !) and with season 5 upon us there are now over 40 tables available. Sure there are a few crap one's but with 3 of my all time arcade favourites in Fish Tales, The Getaway High Speed 2 & Funhouse faithfully reproduced I can't really complain.The interface is getting a bit clunky now with the number of tables available as you have to scroll through a long list to find the table of your choice. Perhaps a future update will address this with search options or being able to arrange the tables by say season, year or manufacturer as well as a favourites option. When the disc versions of Pinball Arcade Hall of Fame came out on PS2 & Wii all the tables were represented in an Arcade with so many tables in each room which worked well so something along those lines would be good as well. My only real gripe is the Pro version of the tables which is just a rip off. Why not make them available for free if you achieve all the wizard goals on a table ?. Above all it's so much fun to play and although I'm a seasoned player I still get frustrated when a ball drains unexpectedly or I tilt the table just short of my all time high score !. But that's what it's all about realistic gameplay that draws you in to having another go. I'm sure you won't regret buying it but I would wait for a sale before buying the earlier seasons. Who know you may get as good as me with lots of practice but I doubt it ! :).

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												It's difficult to give a simple 'Yes' or 'No' for Pinball Arcade. I really enjoy playing the actual tables and if you are pulled towards nostalgia then its great. The biggest problem I have is with the ball physics, but even that isn't a simple good or bad. Some of the tables, like Bride of Pinbot, play great. Other tables, like Funhouse and Tales of Arabian Nights, have terrible physics and the ball seems to defy gravity, floating all around the table. I have seen some people trying to argue that all of the tables play great with real physics; can only assume they live on the moon. It is something you get used to, but it does make it hard to track the ball and makes for readjusting when switching back to a better table. I am surprised they made Tales of Arabain Nights the free table as it is a complete turn-off. This tells me the company is in complete denial if they think that table is good and a sales conviner. I actually didn't buy the Season packs until I read that some tables have great physics and others, like Tales, are terrible. There are also some issues with camera angles being not always the greatest choices especially if you don't want the camera to jump around and track the ball (I'm not a fan of that). I've noticed some tables, like Theater of Magic, have times where they are choppy for a second or two while most run smoothly all of the time. Overall, I recommend this to a pinball fan. I pretty much consider a handfull of the tables (Funhouse and Tales of Arabian Nights for instance) and won't touch them. I'm not sure if they will ever correct the physics for those and I am not sure as to why different tables have better physics than others. If you are new to pinball, I think Pinball FX is much better with consistently smooth physics. After that, if the pinball bug bites,  try Pinball Arcade, but you should check out something other than the free game.

Comes free with full version of Tales of the Arabian Nights pinball machine.Free to Play one pinball machine and the rest are trial runs. Four seasons of pinball machines to buy, season one has 21 machines in it (price 29.99 or 39.99) or buy a table pack with the pinball machine you want. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												What makes this game worthwhile is the faithful recreations of actual pinball tables. The tables are pretty spendy, but it is probably justified by licensing costs. The engine itself is pretty good, but the ball moves faster and feels lighter than it would on an actual pinball table, even immaculate condition machines, which I have played a few. This is only a minor annoyance and the pitch perfect tables are worth the price of admission. The first season is far and away the best deal and has most of the tables you would want anyways. The package is far from perfect however. The UI is awful and little has been done to update it for this platform which really hurts the overall package. The lack of integration with Steam is a missed opportunity considering competing for a high score is a big draw to pinball.  If you love playing actual pinball, this game is for you.If nostalgia isn't part of the package for you, you may be better served with Pinball FX2 which boasts friendslist integration so you can easily see how your friends did on each table and try to beat their top score (which is the reason FX2 is getting more play time from me these days).

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												Pinball Arcade is a wonderful digitization of real world pinball tables.  While the table packs can be a bit on the pricey side, the sheer amount of tables that are available as well as the effort put in to transfer them to game from reality makes Pinball Arcade worthy of you time and money.  This game is not a substitute for the real thing; however, if you find yourself in an area with a derth of pinball machines, it will scratch the itch well enough.  As a bonus, when you do play the real deal, the strategies you pick up here transfer over well.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												If you like pinball at all, most of these tables are a must have. This is as close as you are going to get to perfect pinball on a PC outside a cabinet based sim, and then I'd probably recommend still using this software. I've been able to scratch my pinball itch with all these tables. I've purchased two seasons worth of tables for no small amount of money. I've spent more cash on this game than any other for the last several years. The physics are spot on and most of your typical pinball strategies are applicable. Many of the tables virtualized in this game are quite rare and hard to get to play. Some are great playing and not very popular in the arcades (aka Black Rose). While there is no real substitute for a real table, this is pretty good way to relive some of your favorite tables. Black Rose, Medieval Madness, Star Trek, Bride of Pinbot, and Adams Family are just a few of the ones I recommend you try out. All tables have a certain amount of free play in order to try them.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The Pinball Arcade is without any doubt, some of the best virtual pinball I've played. From it's fluid and realistic ball physics to the attention to details given to the large selection of tables available, it's easy to see why this latest Farsight release as been so highly praised. A collection of some of pinball's most famous tables are at your fingertips, and you're spoilt for choice with legendary tables such as Star Trek The Next Generation, Black Hole, Terminator 2, Bride of Pin-Bot and Theatre of Magic to name just a few. Plus there's the added bonus of the fact that you can experience the Tales of the Arabian Nights table absolutely free of charge. Yes there are other pinball games available, but no other features tables based on their actual real life counterpart and none even come close to being able to match how it plays a game of Pinball. There are improvements that need to be made, but you really can't go wrong with giving this one a try. If you a pinball fan, it's a must play.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												I've always enjoyed pinball machines, even if I'm fairly awful at them. There's something Rube Goldberg-like in all but the most primitive models, and even if bad luck or brutal table design ends my game a few minutes in, it's extremely satisfying getting the various bits and bobs of the table to light up, freak out, and (one can always hope) scream out "MULTIBALL!" I realize they aren't for everyone, but for their enthusiasts, pinball machines are about as magical an arcade fixture as you can hope to find.Of course, the fact that they're finely calibrated physical machines puts some serious dampers on how fun they can be. All too often you'll come across some odd, absurd relic of the 70's, 80's, or 90's, only to find that the thing's been horribly maintained. Unresponsive flippers and broken components are just par for the course. Digital pinball games attempt to correct this; so long as your computer or console can handle the game, how could anything possibly be broken? Unfortunately, with a few exceptions, most pinball video games are either shabbily designed, badly coded, or overly complicated, and by definition none of them can carry the physical element of even the most unloved table.While it's not perfect, FarSight Studios' Pinball Arcade is a wonderful compromise between the physical and digital. Rather than creating new material, they've simply licensed an immense pile of existing tables and digitally recreated them with exhaustive attention to detail and physics. Glitches aren't entirely unheard of, but they're extremely rare, and the ability to play these tables as though they were fresh out of the factory is extremely satisfying. On top of the all-too-natural urge to get high scores on everything, each table comes with 10 achievements to complete (5 Standard Goals and 5 Wizard Goals which are unlocked once you've beaten the first batch), and while selecting your table you get a neat little historical blurb about each one, so you know just who to send hate mail to when The Black Knight unfairly destroys you 12 seconds into the game.The price is a touch high, but this is understandable considering the licensing fees involved, and for fans of the genre, just consider the quarters you'll be saving! If you're still unsure about it, you can install the base game for free to get your hands on one starter table (Tales of the Arabian Nights), and once you've played that one to death, buy a season or two and prepare to lose a few dozen hours.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												If you love pinball simulation, then this game is for you. What sets this game apart from other PC pinball games is that all the tables are recreations of actual physical machines. There is a pretty hefty selection of EM, Solid State, and DMD machines from various eras that will keep you busy for a long time. The prices for tables are a little high but I've gotten enough replay out of it to justify the price. Overall, the game is a little buggy, with some tables glitching out here and there, but most of the time it's great. Although nothing can compare to an actual, real life machine, Pinball Arcade is amazing for learning rules and familiarizing yourself with different tables. Highly recommended!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												The biggest flaw are the horrible floaty physics that don't feel like pinball at all, Balls passing through obstacles. The Web and Timeshock, which came out in 1995 and 1997 respectively, actually felt like a real table.Ugly menu that's up in your face all the time. Want to play a two player game? You can't just hit "Start" twice like you would on the real game. Instead you have to go into the menu, set players to two and then start the game.This setting isn't even remembered between games. If you want to start another multiplayer game after both players drain their last ball, you have to go into the menu again.For some reason I can't enter my initials with a gamepad, even though it works during gameplay. I have to use the flipper buttons on the keyboard instead. Oh and the ugly menu pops up during the highscore entry too. Way to break immersion.Camera likes to bug out during multiballs and show the shooter lane instead of the playfield.Basically, the game is only good for learning the table rules. Fortunately you can do that in "trial mode", without having to buy a single table.

content:

												Nothing can ever fully replicate the tactile experience of playing on a real pinball machine. But given how high-maintenance real tables are, plus how expensive they are in the first place, I am very, very happy that The Pinball Arcade exists.It's not perfect (Cirqus Voltaire, my favorite table ever, needs some serious work on ball physics and Juggler Multiball), but this is BY FAR the best pinball sim out there.But if you're reading this: If you ever find a real machine, even if it's not one of these, please give it a try. There is absolutely nothing else like pinball, and I'm so glad Farsight is helping keep this pastime alive.

I have to use the flipper buttons on the keyboard instead. Oh and the ugly menu pops up during the highscore entry too. Way to break immersion.Camera likes to bug out during multiballs and show the shooter lane instead of the playfield.Basically, the game is only good for learning the table rules. Fortunately you can do that in "trial mode", without having to buy a single table.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												This impressive collection of authentic tables boasts an exceptional fun factor. Most of these landmark arcade tables are professionally well recreated with a staggering attention to detail in glorious 1080p. Yes, many complained that you have to pay for additional tables - and pro packs might be costly for what they really give. Multiplayer ( tournaments ) and DirectX11 features also not available at the release, only later in 2014.  Otherwise gameplay remains rock solid, fluid, physics quite decent,  though as any video pinball  we might sometimes feel gravity/ball weight not as severe as real tables ( thus developers targeting a wider community ). At the same time, experts still need to work hard in order to level up in the leaderboards and completing some challenging 'wizard goals'.Pros:  package of authentic and licensed tables; a blast to play; beautiful and detailed graphics; wide array of goals to achieve.Cons ( minor ) : gravity/ball physics not always as realistic as purists would have liked; no tournaments several weeks after release.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												First half of the game is really frustrating.  It's a series of mini-games, including one called "Find the cursor," and you have to beat them all in order to play any pinball.  The second half of the game, the actual pinball, is much more enjoyable.  Anyway, with "Find the cursor", the programmers warp your mouse to a different position each time you advance to a new menu screen.  Sometimes it's somewhere intuitive, other times it isn't.  You'll just have to move your mouse in little circles and find where the cursor went.  Protip: Check your second monitor if you can't find the cursor. Frustrating game. 2/10Another minigame is "Opposite day."  In this one, you have to guess whether you are enabling or disabling different options.  *Spoiler Alert* If you see a green checkmark, you have disabled that option, the logic being that you have covered your choice so that it is no longer showing. No replay value once you figure it out. 3/10"Make your eyes bleed" is obviously a mobile game ported over to PC.  In MYEB, you navigate big finger friendly icons, which are poorly arranged and hard to read, in order to select which pinball table you would like to play.  Even with at 1080p, you'll still need to scroll in order to see all of the tables.  Can't make those icons any smaller, or turn it into a list, because the mobile version would suffer.  Not the worst game in the world. 4/10"Let's make a deal" is an all too familiar economy sim where buying individual tables becomes a nightmarish and expensive proposition (no refunds allowed).  You'll probably just end up buying a table pack instead, to avoid the frustration.Very realistic. 7/10"Pinball arcade" is the main game.  It faithfully recreates old pinball tables with realistic-ish physics.  Really fun experience, bar some rare, but annoying bugs and outdated graphics.Good effort. 8/10Overall 5/10

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												If you are a pinhead (pinball enthusiast), you should already have this. I love being able to play simulations of classic pinball machines from my youth. With the introduction of DirectX 11, the tables look pretty good and I appreciate the controller support. I have the Pro Packs of Season 1 and 2 and will eventually get them all when on sale. I really like the additional features in this game like the flyers, the history facts about the tables, and the pro tips. I also have this game on the Xbox 360 but with only some of the season 1 tables, but have pretty much abandoned the console version after the whole Microsoft distribution debacle that kept many of the season one tables, as well as all the other seasons, from being released on that platform for so long.If you are not a pinhead, but are curious, you should check this out anyway for historical purposes. Pinball machines were video games before video games were invented (well, the old electro-mechanical machines, anyway).

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												I said I'd recommend this game, with some huge caveats.I specifically got this game, and paid for a table pack, because I'm obsessed with one particular table. I don't know of a publically playable one anywhere in my vicinity. So for $5 I was able to get the table I wanted. They don't let you buy the tables individually, so it came with a bunch of tables I don't want. That didn't particular bother me because I would have payed that much just for the table I want. They do an EXCELLENT job of recreating the tables to look and play exactly like the real ones. Like this is actually an amazing way to learn about all the game play functionality of your favorite tables. It helped me learn HOW to play my favorite table in much more detail than I had known before. In general the attention to detail on all the tables is pretty incredible. The game just has one major downside, and that is the physics engine that governs the ball. I've played and watched a fair amount of REAL pinball. Many simulators have a thing where you hit the ball and it'll like only half roll up the table, like you hit it softly. This simply doesn't happen in the real world. All the balls are weighted the same and the paddles only hit at one speed and strength. So on my favorite table, it's actually frequently difficult to hit the ball such that it even makes it to the top of the table. Not only is this annoyingly unrealistic, it actually makes playing the game VERY difficult. So DO play this game if you're looking for a cheap game that's decently fun and allows you to reminice and maybe even learn some new things about tables you remember from back in the day. Do NOT play this game if you're looking for a full digital experience that matches the real table. It just doesn't.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												With over 300+ hours now invested in this game, I can now safely say that Pinball Arcade comes as close as you can to actual pinball play as any simulation or game on the PC today, Pinball FX, and Pro Pinball included. If I were to break this review down in scores of 1 to 10, I would give each of the following these scores:Presentation: 8/10 - A wide range of tables, producers, styles, and time frames of pinball, from the basic bell & whistle games to the more recent electronic gems like Addams Family. My down marks for this is that the PC version does not include the history of pinball videos that the Android version does, which to me greatly enhances the package, or lack thereof.Graphics: 8/10 - Since Farsight got the licenses for these tables, their dedication to accuracy shows. Some pieces are missing, (Christopher Lloyd - Addams Family), due to contractual agreements, but wherever possible, FS has stuck as close to the original design of the table as they can. There was recently an update to DirectX 11, and if you have the system to run it, the graphical improvement is definitely noticeable.Gameplay: 7.5/10 - Gameplay only suffers IMO due to an over adbundance of the need to "nudge" or shake a table, and if you are someone like myself who doesn't use this 'ability', the tables seem to penalize you by the ball consistently draining on side lanes, taking odd tracks, and a general REPEAT of the same ball play even in multiple player games. Also, as Steam Achievements are included in PA, once you have obtained a few decent scores on a game, it seems as the difficulty is somehow magically increased, thus making further achievements difficult if not almost impossible (Addams Family Super Bear Bonus for example). Aside from this each table has its on nuances and tricks, from Terminator 2, to Haunted House.Variety: 8.5/10 - It is here where PA shines as they have tables from the major players in the profession, Bally, Williams, Gotlieb, wide-body tables, multi-level tables, and of course, the most popular pinball table in history, Addams Family.Price: 6/10 - As has been mentioned in other reviews, the pricing model for PA is IMO its biggest weakness. Tales of Arabian Nights comes as a free table, but the other tables all have to be purchased, either seperately, or through Season packs. I have all of the tables except for a couple from Season 3, all but 3 from Season 4, and none from Season 5 yet, and had these season packs gone on sale at an earlier date, I could have saved about 20 - 30% of my total cost in the game. Also, even though PA is cross-platform (Steam, IOS, Android, console, PC), purchases on one platform do not carry over to the others. So if you want for example the Addams Family on both your tablet and your PC, you would be paying for 2 copies. The before mentioned missing history videos are a part of this as well.In conclustion, Pinball Arcade is a great recreation and a good way to travel back to the time when smokey rooms, stale coke, and the sounds of pinball machines filled the air. It is not perfect, but then what is?UPDATE: 06/24/16 -  A new user interface has been updated on the game since this review was first done, and IMO has seriously downgraded the play of Pinball Arcade. It is hard to navigate through menus without the use of a controller or mouse, and actually gameplay has been reduced greatly, my own scores for example have been cut by at least a 1/3 since the update to this new UI. This doesn't change my overall opinion of PA, but it does blemish what could otherwise be a great collection of classic pinball.UPDATE 11/22/16 - Although some of the bugs with some tables still exist, the new user interface has ben vastly improved, and there is really no good reason not to try out this fantastic pinball recreation.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Of all the games I've bought on Steam, this is the only one that has actually revoked itself from my library. There apparently is a 'contact us' about getting the collection back, and you have to send payment details and other nonsense. This alone makes me never, ever, want to trust these people with a purchase. That's right, I had one of the collections in my library, and it was removed for no reason (as it was for many people). Like PBFX2, the game itself is a poor console port with graphics that are actually superior on consoles than pc. "they are working on it" lol.If you format / install on other computers, you will have your high scores overwritten. This dev is clueless on how to make a game work correctly. The tables are nice recreations of real tables, but the whole thing is very feature lacking, you have to pay double for such features as "free look" meaning getting to move the camera around... which is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid. And frankly most of the time the tables just aren't that fun. Also the collections are very expensive. Don't support console scrub developers who don't care or understand how to make a PC game. This is a very amateurish endeavor.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Okay, the game (steam-version) has some issues. The graphics are not up to date. Some bugs in it, but which game has no bugs?And, unfortunately, a not well implemented friends list and a half decent operator menu.But, that is only one side of the coin. On the other hand you have the best simulation of pinball machines on the market.Physics are great. The ball seems to have weight. The older pinball games have not that good ball physics. A big variety of tables. I´ve never heard of a manufacturer, who made so much (real examples) tables available. Some of the tables are astonishing. I´m never bored and I´m playing every day for 1-2 hours (maybe more ;-))As a member of pinball community you are not sinking in the crowd like in "bigger" games. Devs take part of discussion.TPA will be updated in the next months (better graphics DX11).And for me important; While playing pinball, the issues have hardly a stitch on me, because I´m concentrating on movement of the ball! For that reason updates needs to be made, but for me they are not coactive. I have fun with the game in its current state! So, if you like pinball, buy it !!!

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												If you really love pinball it's a great little program, very faithful recreations of actual tables, however the textures on the tables are not as good as they should be. Ball physics is a little weird but there's not much you can do about that.Unfortunately I have to give this a thumbs down because it is incredibly buggy. The UI is all kinds of messed up, sometimes you can't use the menus at all, using a gamepad to navigate the UI rarely works, and in the short time I've played several times I've hit start and the game doesn't go, it gets stuck in the table fly-by animation and I need to exit the table. Also a lot of stuff, like what the graphics settings do, what the pro features are, etc. are poorly communicated.It's the best pinball simulation available right now, but it's a shame it lacks so much polish. Only buy a few tables you really like.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I'm a pinball fan from way back, so I was excited to hear about this title, and real world tables modeled? Icing on the cake.  Sadly however, icing is all this really is.  I was underwhelmed by the ball physics, which felt rather ping-pong ball light, and the flipper action lacked weight.  Worse still - the inability to intuitively set the view to a simple overhead that doesn't require any screen flipping was a complete deal killer for me.  It's possible I suppose, that the ability to put the view the way I want it does exist - and if someone would like to point it out to me, I'll give this another fair shot.  But for now? It was uninstalled very quickly indeed and I've no plans to return to it.With that said - pinball still kicks♥♥♥♥♥ So what to do?  I have one word for you : timeshock!   The ProPinball series of original pinball tables is the absolute gold standard for computer-based pinball as far as I'm concerned, and that opinion hasn't changed in over a decade.  Head over to Greenlight and check out the HD editions they're currently trying to put to the light of day.  If you love pinball - these guys deserve your support unreservedly.Other alternatives - the Pinball FX2 on Steam is in most cases, acceptable and entertaining, though not exceptional. If you absolutely have to have your real-world modeled pinball?  Google PinMAME and do a little research.  It's more work to set up, but it'll get you the real-world tables you crave.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Although it's advertised as a free to play game, Pinball Arcade is simply a giant Demo that comes with 50+ recreated pinball tables, but only lets you play one table fully. The other 50 tables that came downloaded can only be played until you hit a high score and then you're kicked out, although you're allowed to replay them as many times as you want.If you're downloading this looking for a free game to waste a couple of hours on, then it shouldn't matter since you can still have fun flailing the tables around with the tilting feature, and if you end up losing all your balls before you hit a high score then the limits won't be a real issue for you.The problem is that after a while you just get tired of the game, there's no way for you to move on or unlock any more tables freely. Taking out highscores leaves you with really no point to replay a table or try to improve. Instead you feel punished for improving. It's like minigolf, the worse you are, the longer you get to play it. The better you are at getting points, the faster you'll be kicked out off the tables.I wish the free version of the game would give you more. I'd love it if you could unlock one more free table by completing achievements, or even just being able to choose backround music to replace the silence/crappy music of some pinball tables.When you go to buy a table, it just feels unneedlessly complicated to give three options of buying, but none of them let you just buy the single table you want! Your choices are to buy the 30$ season pack, a 5$ pack for 2 tables, and then ussually a 8$ "Pro" pack version that never has it's differences explained ingame.You're out of luck if you just want a single table in the pack, and the second table included is one that you couldn't care less about. There's not much flexibility with your choices or any real alternatives to that, and it just doesn't feel like a value if part of the price you're paying is for a table you'll never use.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Pinball Arcade is a little different from most digital pinball games in that all of the tables are replicas, or near replicas of real classic pinball tables. This fact is one of the reasons I like the game so much, it helps though that not only are real tables in the game but there are brief but detailed descriptions of each table along with a snippet of the the tables history. The game features one free table, and lets you play the others as a trial before you decide if you want to purchase them, a feature common with most pinball games at this time. Pinball Arcade is free so if you like Pinball you should at least give this game a try, you never know you might learn something about pinball along the way.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												ahhhh Nostalgia. Being a older gamer, I remember when kids used to congregate at the mall arcade to see and play the latest and greatest in a blossoming video game industry. In this age of bleep blop beloop 8-bit graphics there sat in the corner the legacy of the last great gaming icons. The pinball machines. Like dinosaur bones they just looked really cool but no one would really play those when you had sitdown SpyHunter or Tron Discs to drop tokens on. Yet I was attracted to these machines, whose art and design were always such a pleasure to see. And when games started rising to 2 tokens per play, the pinball machines stayed at one. So i started playing them, Black Knight, Fun House, Adams Family, etc.... and I gained an appreciation for the ancestor to my hobby. Now all the arcades are dead. Im an old guy with a job i work too hard at. So when I found out about this recreation of the machines that were so cool to me back in the day, I immediately loved it. These painstakingly recreated pinball machines pull me right back into that mall arcade in 1986. If youre a retro gamer, if you like pinball...you will appreciate this game.8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Quick review to start: Holy cow is this ever fun to play!  The only caveat to recommending the Pinball Arcade is that, naturally, it's all about pinball and maybe that doesn't float your boat.  I do believe that pinball is universally entertaining however if you accept the inherent gameplay mechanics and so if you play this game you'll find happiness.This is the second major pinball system on Steam now, but I will rate it unquestionably the best.  Why?  Because it *feels* perfect.  All the physics involved has a very satisfying sense of weight to it... the ball accelerates believably, the timing of when you strike the ball with your flippers affects the trajectory properly, and the rebounds from bumpers and sidewalls fits your expectations just *right*.  This is absolutely the best playing pinball experience you'll find on Steam.  There IS still room for improvement however but those are fiddly details that you'll hardly notice (the ball never leaves the table surface making certain actions reliably consistent compared with reality, the flippers are rock-solid and don't have any "spongeyness" that happens with real tables, and the friction of the table surface and steel rails is constant which again makes the ball behavior suffer no random deviations).  I've been familiar with pinball games, but I'm not a nut for the genre, and so I'm not bothered by the lack of absolute authenticity with the real tables.  Each game that's recreated here scores high by replicating a faithful experience.  You probably won't be able to "train" on these virtual recreations and expect perfect knowledge about how to work the real thing, but you WILL get all the entertainment that was built into the original games.  And on the note about those original games.... WOW!  The variety of tables to play is astonishing from truly old school pinball experiences from the 1960's to classic 70's and 80's table complete with early arcade sounds (I *love* those sounds!) to the zenith of pinball evolution in the mid 1990's.  The Pinball Arcade is truly a museum piece approach to the genre that shows no favorites for any one time period or manufacturer.  The breadth of choice is very, very nice!Some other things to note: all the tables present in this game are recreations of the originals which were designed to eat your money.  This is important to remember because even though there's no longer any quarters being spent to play there can be a lot of frustrating moments where your game ends prematurely because happenstance physics will cause your ball to drain no matter how skillful you can play.  It's possible to "nudge" the machine in multiple directions in an attempt to coax the ball into a different trajectory but I can't count how many times I've had terrible games because the ball just dumps itself down the drain prematurely.  Another important thing is that the game is going to be receiving a visual upgrade in 2014 when the developers release a DirectX 11 patch that adds much more modern lighting support and (hopefully!) texture map resolution bumps.  The game looks great already but these two additions will make the experience even more lifelike and exciting.  I do have some gripes to make about the game however.  Currently there's no support for Steam Friends in game, which is something that Zen Studio's "Pinball FX 2" supports and I miss it.  You are encouraged to make a FarSight Studios account in order to have your scores ranked against other people, but there's something mighty satisfying about seeing your scores compared with people you actually know on Steam, and that's just not present right now.  Another complaint is that the Steam release still shows heavy connections to the Pinball Arcade releases on lower performance hardware (tablets, iphone, Android, etc.).  The game still PLAYS fantastic, but there's a level of spit and polish to the user interface and camera controls that's just not right for a PC game and cheapens the experience.  The last thing I have to say about the base Pinball Arcade experience concerns the Free-to-Play nature of the title.  "Free-to-Play"... eh.... it is and it isn't.  When you download the game from Steam you will be downloading ALL the tables which you can play as long as you want UP UNTIL THE FIRST HIGH SCORE.  This is actually rather generous because it means there's no time's-up-and-you're-locked-out-until-you-buy penalty, and in practice I found that the minimum high score threshold is high enough for you to play for a good amount of time in a single game and it's only when you really start getting your skill up that you find yourself hitting that ceiling.  Once you do starting bumping up to that limit you'll likely have found some favorite tables to play and you can then purchase them individually or all at once via the Season Packs.  There's even one pinball machine you can play forever (Tales of the Arabian Nights) that is extremely fun and definitely not a "throwaway bone" for the FTP monicker.  For all that this offers for free I say check it out right away and see if it finds a place in your heart... there's a lot to love here and I daresay if you're not a pinball fan when you start playing you will be when you're finished.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												There have been a ton of awesome pinball tables over the years and Pinball Arcade is one of the best programs to come along so far to deliver the experience of digital pinball with actual table designs from years gone by. Granted, if you're not into pinball, there's nothing really here for you, but without spending any money you do get full access to one table and can demo every other table without paying a dime.PROS: Very good (though not perfect) physics, table designs are nearly spot-on to the real machines, includes a mix of various tables from the most popular to the least popular, as well as from the most common to the absurdly rare, actual ROM data is being used so the tables have all of their hidden features and everything, all of which are documented in-game, extensive instructions available for every table to make learning the rulesets much easier.CONS: Default configuration and camera settings are garbage for anyone looking to REALLY play the game, so you need to reconfigure everything, the "Call Attendant" feature for dealing with issues can't handle most of the problems which crop up (which are thankfully few and far between), very expensive if you want "pro" access to all the tables (extra configuration settings and options for examining the table)... still cheaper than owning just a single REAL machine. :P

I wouldn't say "Arabian Nights" plays precisely like the arcade- the slope of the table seems a little steep- but on the positive side, I've seen very few real-world versions of the table where every moving part worked as well and smoothly as it should, so that's definitely a plus.The death of this for me is disk space. 11.3 GB for the one free table I play once in a blue moon. Pinball is like solitaire for me- something I pick up when I want a quick, ten minute game fix, not a three-hour session. I would be far more likely to consider buying more content if the game didn't seem to store every bloody table on my hard drive under the premise that I *might* want to buy them and they should be instantly available the moment I did. As 'tis, I let this go to free up the hard disk space.Some reviewers have commented that this seems like a port from one of the mobile versions, but I'm going to hazard a guess that the mobile versions don't try to store every possible sale item on your tablet.Bad call on that decision, Farsight. If you ever update this so it doesn't take up more space than Saint's Row III, I will probably chip in for "Midieval Madness". As it is- get off my computer!

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												PInball has been around for well over a decade longer than video games, and has evolved in interesting fashions over the years. And for almost as long as there have been video games, there have been video games attempting to bring the pinball experience into a video game. For my entire life, I've played pinball, and tried pinball video games. None of them came close - they could not adequately imitate the freedom of a steel ball rolling freely across a painted wooden table, hitting things, and bouncing back out. They made games that looked like pinball, but didn't feel like Pinball. Even the Pinball FX series, as good as it is, still doesn't feel like a real ball spinning across a table freely. Pinball Arcade is the first game I've ever felt came as close as possible to what pinball is. And they do this not by imitating pinball, but by digitizing pinball - by taking real pinball tables, and scanning them - not just taking pictures of the machines, but by taking them apart and scanning each and every part fully and completely - not just how the parts look, but how they weigh, feel, and act. As a result, they end up doing what other pinball games never have - they make the game feel very, very close to playing the same pinball table as you would find in an arcade. The tables offered are recreations of the same tables, and for all but a minor detail, they feel the same. I have a hard time believing that any video game pinball can get the same tactile feel that true pinball tables have, and this is the one aspect that Pinball Arcade doesn't adequately duplicate. But they're closer than any other video game pinball has ever been - as close as I believe is possible. But if it's possible to take that last step, and get the same tactile sensation of having the ball roll across the table and feel the faint vibrations in your hands... I think that the team at Farsight Studios are the people who can make it happen. The only downside that Pinball Arcade has right now is that their core UI for selecting tables is based on a touch-screen or controller system, and doesn't work cleanly with a computer's mouse-based interface, and almost doesn't work at all by keyboard. This is supposedly being updated and revamped soon, though, so I don't really mark them down too hard on this. The gameplay - when you're actually playing the pinball machine - is still very well-done. If you like real-life pinball, this is the game you want to play.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This has nothing to do with the game Pinball Arcade, otherwise, you will just never believe what just happened.But before that; recovering from my last experience I decided, as an alternative, not to reinstall, but to mount and manually delete the system folder containing all the updates. After starting, I was rid of all the causes regarding my complaints. ...Back to Pinball Arcade.  foofaraw brought me here. I was still wondering about how real the feeling would be. Not so much what you see, but giving that memory lane feel to the better days when handling the real thing itself. That interested me.  So let's download the thing. The whole installation was top-notch as what you would expect. The system popups exactly as predicted. Only to discover that flipper controls are best with keyboard, not mouse.The graphics created a visual what triggered the 3D in my inner eye. But I was missing something. The essence of the dance I had with the machines. Nudging softly enough to have some random good effect, and not so hard that it triggers tilt with some randomly bad penalty. How do you bump the cabinet?Puzzled browsing the control settings I found that it was setup for a joystick. But that will not work, I can't hold both shifts and a joystick simultaneously. My mind was wandering if there would be console-like pinball themes controllers when suddenly my system froze.  Only a hard reset was left, my system restarted. I was surprised and totally baffled seeing more words than expected. Focusing it read "Update bewerking 2376 van toepassing 5736". ?!?!After completion, the re-startup took about 20 minutes. Desktop... no changes to be seen. Lesson learnt: i'm keeping a camera waiting prepared to capture the next time something happens.

Give us some visibility options.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												My love of this game mostly stems from breathless nostalgia, as in "I wonder if it has Cactus Canyon OH MY GOD IT DOES and OH WOW there's Whirlwind I haven't played that since I was a kid and HOLY CRAP FUNHOUSE I was terrified of that one!!". If you've ever played any of the tables featured, definitely check it out.I've also come to appreciate the game as kind of a historical museum. I'm not really a pinball afficianado, but I do like browsing through the tables and seeing how trends came and went over the decades. The transition from electromechanical to solid state, the way targets gave way to ramps, the fascination with multiple playfields and flippers that slowly died out, etc. I dunno, it's interesting.If I had to criticize the game, I'm not a fan of how most tables come in packs of two. I bought Cactus Canyon and found myself saddled with Central Park. Don't get me wrong, I appreciate the charms of an electromechanical table, but I'd really prefer something more traditional, like Big Shot. But if I bought Big Shot I'd also get Scared Stiff, which I didn't care too much for, and yeah, you see where this is going.I'm not knowledgable enough to discuss the physics and how accurate they are. It SEEMS like the ball should be going faster than it is. Compare any gameplay video of a table in Pinball Arcade to a video of its real-life counterpart and you can definitely see a difference. Maybe it's just a matter of perspective. Most videos of real pinball games are shot either from the side or from straight up, and it's been far too long since I've been to an arcade to remember if it feels any different.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Not only am I huge fan of hit arcade games from the 90's but I'm also a huge one of Pinball machines. When I was a little child of ADHD mental disability these things took me by storm with flashy lights, corespondant dot matrix display that interacted with the action, ramps, rails and rabbit holes, and what's even harder to believe is that all the ones I've seen in real life are there too. Attack From Mars, still can't get a straight shot to that UFO. Haunted House made me scream in terror when I heard "Old Man Death" play as my ball slipped into the drain. Funhouse brought back memories of smelling freshly cooked hot wings in the bowling alley and the smell of adreniline pumping with every press of the buttons. I give this game a very nostalgic score of S+, for SUPERBLY ADDICTINGLY AWESOME!

content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												This pinball simulator is awesome!!! I have been looking for something like this for a long time now and for them to offer freeplay is spectacular to allow you to get the feel for their work. They have really thought long and hard about this simulator and it really shows. You can of course just skip all the reading and go in, select your choice of pinball game, click the free mode to avoid buying or spending any money and play up to whatever the limit of score is on that game. There is one unlocked table you can play. It might seem kind of steep in price but I actually think it is worth it if you really love some of these pinball machines! Think about it this way, a real pinball machine cost from maybe $400 and up (sky is the limit) and they will not usually be in the best of shape or condition. Then you have to have a means of getting the machine to where you live or where you intend on putting it, then you might have to have it serviced, repaired, or tuned. Then... did it come with any of the original manuals, articles, history, or know-how about how the game is to be played, the scoring, and all the wizardy integrated into advanced possible features of the machine (90% of the time, no)? In this simulator, the games sound great and original, the visuals are as if you have your machine in beyond mint condition... forever, there is no service to have to have on the game... it just works! And, if you have a mobile computer with fast enough GPU, it's completely portable! This simulator works perfect on my higher end desktop PC and I have enjoyed getting into all of the reading material included too. The actions, sounds, gameplay mechanics, everything is there.Now... developers if you are reading this... how about getting those amazing Pirates of the Caribbean pinball machines into the game? I would definitely buy that one as I was trying to figure out how to recreate one in VirtualPinball on my own... it's deffinitely not easy yet you have done all the hard work for everyone here on Steam! Thank you! Now take my money and make more pinball machines! :D

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Nostalgia TripFor many years I've always wanted to relive those years playing the pinball machines I grew up with. Finally here it is at last. Sure there are a few quirks and bugs here and there, but that is to be expected when it comes to emulating real world physics and they aren't as bad as in Pinball Zen. I only hope to see the rest of the machines that were made during the 1980s and the 1990s such as Comet, Cyclone, and Getaway: High Speed II which are the ones I grew up with. There is no other pinball game like this today.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												It has all the Pins I remember as a kid. The games look great and sound great. The issue is that the physics are not 1:1 to a real Pinball machine. So the Pinball's feel "videogamey". So things like bumbs and other trick shots can be difficult to pull off. But if you want something that is close to what one of these machines plays like, there is not another platform that has all these offical classic pinball machines.  Also the games are sold in packs or solo. The best deal is to get season 1-2 when they go on sale, since those seasons have all the big name pins from the 60's to the 90's. Overall the best way to play pinball without dropping 5k on a used machine or driving miles away to play a single pinball machine.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												8/10 (price is steep)If you are a fan of pinball (which I am) this might be the closest you will ever get to owning your own table. I’ve played all the machines as their real-life counterparts and this game does an incredible job of recreating the experience. It is an expensive game when you factor in all three seasons worth of content but if you are a fan of the genre then you understand it’s a very small investment to own such a high-quality collection of tables. The game has a few older tables but recent updates have really focused on more modern games; which is nice. If you like pinball I would recommend this game wholeheartedly and definitely recommend it over Pinball FX.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Not only am I huge fan of hit arcade games from the 90's but I'm also a huge one of Pinball machines. When I was a little child of ADHD mental disability these things took me by storm with flashy lights, corespondant dot matrix display that interacted with the action, ramps, rails and rabbit holes, and what's even harder to believe is that all the ones I've seen in real life are there too. Attack From Mars, still can't get a straight shot to that UFO. Haunted House made me scream in terror when I heard "Old Man Death" play as my ball slipped into the drain. Funhouse brought back memories of smelling freshly cooked hot wings in the bowling alley and the smell of adreniline pumping with every press of the buttons. I give this game a very nostalgic score of S+, for SUPERBLY ADDICTINGLY AWESOME!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												First off: This is the best Pinball Simulation ever! Non of the competing pinball games of the recent years even come close to the overall presentation and feeling of Pinball arcade. Every table in this game is an extremely detailed digital replica of a realworld table. Everything is faithfully simulated, every light, sound and even the backboards. Nice touch: Every table comes with a little bit of trivia, where you can learn about it's original creators and history.The pinball machines are sold separately or in season packs. Buying a season pass saves you a good amount of money over buying the tables separately. The amount and variety of tables in every season is spot on. OK, some tables are not my cup of tea, but the majority is very interesting and I love playing them.There is just one little thing that I don't like about this game: The developers want extra cash for a so called "pro" version of their tables. The difference is that you are able to access the operators menu that every table has, where you are able to change the amount of balls or at what score you get an extra ball. It seems a bit greedy to me, that I would have to pay extra for something like that.For an arcade freak like me this game is just great and highly recommended.My verdict: 9/10 - Great game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I felt I had to redo this review mainly because so much has changed. The game supports DX11 now and on my screen it looks great. Some people have had issues with the new User Interface and some table problems. I did play a few games of pinball today 06/26/2016  and I had no issues to report. I did play in DX11 and man do the tables just sparkle with DX11 compared to DX9. Some people despise the new user interface. Its not perfect for sure. However its ok. I suppose it could be  better. However I havent had a crash yet on both a Laptop W10 with a newish i3 using onboard graphics only. I have also played this on my desktop W10 with a nvidia 750ti. Still no crashes. I do think people have an unrealistic view on some issues. The sound issue is a biggie. Most pinballs had mono sound. Not stereo like a lot of people think. Also some pinball ROMS just are not very good because the tables were flaky in real life. High Roller Casino I am looking at you. Grrrrr.  Also most  people playing this are not going to notice the small things that are wrong with some of the tables. That being said Pinball Arcade is not perfect however it is solid in my opinion. If you really want to see bad pinball look at Fantastic Pinball Thrills. Very awful reviews for a reason bad gameplay.  So I am not saying the tables are not without fault. I have heard of people saying the game will crash.  However I have not had it crash on me yet. I did play a few games in DX9 as well. I could not get the game to crash during my play time. So if your like me  and loved the old pinball games and dont have thousands to spend on the real deal or have the space then this is a good buy. The ball physics are the top of the line and the tables are mostly like I remember them being. Also I want to mention Zaccaria Pinball as its not getting the love and attention it deserves. Granted the tables are older and not as cutting edge as Pinball Arcade however give it a chance and play the free table. Its a good game of pinball and a good team of dedicated people over their.. The game comes with one table unlocked and the others have a score limit so you can play them and see if you like them. I think this is a golden age for pinball players like us. We have so many choices now its crazy good.
