content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												If you like pinball based on real machines this is the only commercial game that I know of that captures any of the excitement of real pinball. Watch out though, once you buy it on one platform you may find yourself wanting to buy it for android/ios and the tables do not transfer between platforms. You may want to consider that before you buy it. One of my favorite features for this version includes the ability to put it in portrait mode on a widescrieen monitor that you have twisted 90*. I am very tempted to get a cheap TV and an old laptop and mount the TV on legs for a dedicated portrait video pinball "cabinet". A few bits and bobs and some keymappnig later and you should be able to work in flippers, plungers, start buttons, and a tilt sensor. :)

												This offers very good gameplay for a Pinball video game (and possibly the best one I've ever seen) with the fancy high graphics and with a reliable frame rate, this maybe the greatest pinball experience that will ever be displayed on the PC.The lighting, visual effects and objects are stunning even the ball and playing fields. I like that you can buy more tables in packs for more pinball fun and even if you dont want to buy tables, YOU GET ONE FREE! 												Love everything about it!!!!  It is now my number one game to go to.  Playing all the old pins from the 70s on up just make me smile. content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												There needs to be more options. I think that the whole Pro pack thing is dumb. Features that should be included in the regular editon especially for these prices. I've enjoyed the tables themselves but overall, nothing is so impressive that it feels like a fair value. You pay for a season because its stupid to buy individual tables but then you end up with a few table that are fun and you wanted, and a buch that are kind of crap. The menus and UI are complete junk. Clunky, ugly, annoying. Exactly the same as it was in the console game "william's pinball arcade" that came out years ago. Same music and sound FX too! Maybe thats why im turned off by the prices. I paid $10 for that disc and it had so many tables. All you had to do was unlock them by playing. I get it, they have to pay fees, whatever, if they made it more worthwhile to pay $30+ per season I wouldn't care. While I may eventually give in to the prices, I'm not gonna like it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I've turned around on this one. At first, I didn't care much for the old school approach. It isn't REALLY accurate. If it were, I could smack and kick the table.....and lose ridiculous amounts of quarters just to get my name on the top score. (I don;'t think that will be happening on this.) I've found a few tables I played back in the day. That's what won me over....nostalgia.Having said that, Pinball FX2 is modern and faster and fits the times. This one is NOT real pinball. It's a simulation of real pinball. There are things in REAL pinball that you can do with hand /eye/body cooridantion that you can't do here. What do I mean by body? When paying real pinball,you can move, angle , shake the table, nudge lightly or hard. That's impossible to duplicate . So, to me, having been a real arcade-troll who actually played Elvira's table, and the Black Hole table, anyone who says this is real ...hasn't played real pinball.Why do I like PinballFX2 better? It could be nothing more than the modern feel and the graphics. The gameplay is fairly similar....although Pinball Arcade doesn't alllow for a small space between lower flippers, which is accurate, FX2 makes up for it in speed and the need to be extremely accurate . It also employs video game animations and character models. Does that mean I don't like this game? Nah. It's fine I just think the argument that it's REAL and FX2 isn't is absurd. The other thing is, Pinball FX offers up better graphics out of the box....no need to have any special video card bs....or knowledge of how to change your video settings so you can play. THAT'S effed up.  They need to fix that and lower the prices. They want you to think they've done something special. They didn't even design the tables if you think about it. So....why pay more? I don't know. Seems like nothing more than el;itism and greed to me.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												This review covers Black Hole, Ripley's Believe It or Not, Tales of the Arabian Nights and Theatre of Magic. I will edit the review if and when I buy and play more tables.The pinball physics engine is really good for the most part. There are some noticeable ball speed issues where they seem to move at unrealistically fast speeds in comparison to real-life pinball machines. Depending on the table, there are some major differences between the quality of the textures and sounds, but it's usually acceptable. The worst textures are of the flooring and walls, but those can't really be considered as being parts of the tables. It would be nice if the developers actually made an effort to polish every facet of the game though, since the flooring and walls are also part of the gaming experience. At the time of this writing we are waiting on an apparently big DirectX 11 patch, but there's no telling if the overall look and presentation will actually be improved or if more negative aspects will be erroneously added because of the update. Let's hope it's a positive change.Some tables seem to be plagued by various bugs. I'm not sure if these bugs are also present in the real-life machines, but in Ripley's Believe It or Not, there are some game breaking bugs. Balls will get stuck and the game engine doesn't recognize some key moments, and these bugs will make you stuck. The only way to fix it is to quit the game and go back. I've contacted support about these bugs and they said that they are aware of these bugs and are working on fixes at the time of this writing.All four tables I played seem to be emulated well, despite the issues I've mentioned earlier. What's great about Pinball Arcade is that all tables available are based on actual real-life machines. You won't find any digital pinball related gimmicks or gameplay mechanics. This game is almost like an unlimited, interactive museum of these classic gaming machines where physics, reflexes, and skills are all that matter. On the other hand, in addition to the lack of overall polish and some bugs, my other complaint is about their pricing model. I understand some people may feel that $30 per pack is reasonable, but I feel that it's a mistake. If the prices were lower and if there were good sales, I'm sure they would sell much more on Steam. It also seems like the Steam/PC platform is not their priority, as they appear to be spending much more time with other platforms. Overall, if you have an interest in playing real-life pinball machines on your PC, this is probably one of the best options available, and new tables are supposed to be added on a monthly basis.Pinball Arcade is good.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												I'm having fun playing The Twilight Zone on this table, but mainly because I have access to the real table and it's fun to see it on the computer.Unfortunately there are a couple of fatal bugs in the game's feature "Lost In The Zone" mode where afterward the game is unable to load the balls back into the "gumball machine" so the plunger is flooded with 3 balls at a time until you reset the table. It doesn't even recover on the next game without resetting the table. Another fatal mistake is that the multi-ball modes don't reliably auto-launch balls into play. Many of the balls that should be auto-launched are simply dropped to the manual plunger which is distracting and actually changes the gameplay.Beyond the flaws in the table I've played the game suffers from extremely predictable physics. There is no randomness in how balls are released into play so it is very easy to predict where a ball will settle when introduced into the table.I recommend this game to anyone who is looking to play a specific table that they know this simulator has available. If you simply want a fun pin ball experience there are better alternatives out there.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												I have been playing this game on iOS, Android, and PS4 for quite some time. The PC version of the game is competent, but doesn't run as well as I would expecton my PC (6700K/GTX1080) in DX11. For the price, however, I would expect better performance. And price is the issue with this game. To have every table, the total price as of the time of this review is $419.88. In no way is the game worth anything close to that. And for all of the praise these tables get...they are NOWHERE near the real deal. I am lucky enough to have a Pinball museum within driving distance to my house, and I have played many of these tables in person. These tables are good approximations, but you can't really say "Well, a real table would be $7K, so $7 for a pro version is a good deal." This is software, and its price does not correspond to its quality, especially without crossplatform play. Pinball Arcade seems, at its core, to be an excercise in monetization, delivered via Pinball- and as such it cannot be recommended.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is the only current game on PC that simulates actual physical pinball tables, and it does it well.   I highly recommend Pinball Arcade for those "purists" who don't love having a bunch of cartoon characters dancing around the table as you play.  The physics are entertaining but not as accurate as some rabid fans might suggest and I truly hope Farsight further tweaks them.  Occasionally the game will get weird with "helium ball" or super slowdown where everything including sound & music runs and stays at around 1/4 speed.  These things will right themselves after restarting Steam.Another issue on my laptop, which has Intel integrated + Nvidia dedicated graphics, is that Pinball Arcade's configuration utility only recognizes the integrated graphics.  Performance is still fine, but the flipper has about a 1/5 second input lag (really bad for pinball) which can be somewhat alleviated by turning off v-sync.  Hello screen tearing!  On my desktop PC that only has dedicated Nvidia graphics, there is no problem.Hopefully the promised upgrades (already in use on PS4 and Xbone) will be added to Pinball Arcade soon.08/16/2016 Update-  Performance has actually worsened considerably since I first typed this review.  It seems that with every patch, Pinball Arcade has worsening extreme slowdown issues making it unplayable for me.  Both Pinball FX and Zaccaria Pinball are quite smooth but not Pinball Arcade.  I guess I'll have to upgrade to compensate for sloppy programming...

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												There’s a nostalgic attraction to the concept of digital preservation - and the craft involved with an elaborate pinball table is an art. Leading the charge for commercial video pinball sim, Pinball Arcade seeks to emulate authentic tables as closely as possible.A digital platform, the base package includes (depending on version) either 1 or 4 real life tables of historical note. New tables are added in packs of 2 as they’re recreated. Farsight has done a good job of mixing older tables with new; simple but groundbreaking boards such as Black Hole are represented along with relatively modern bombastic crowd pleasers such as Medieval Madness. A strong aspect of the package is well-explained rule sheets with visual aids. If you thought pinball was sheer randomness, and never knew most tables have an intricate sequence of modes to activate for huge jackpots, Farsight’s respect for the game is contagious.The only downside is a fundamentals-first ethic, leaving the presentation with the look of a cheap iOS game even in the console versions. Farsight intends to update the front end, but it’s a drag compared to the virtual arcade hangouts in the developer’s earlier generation Pinball Hall of Fame collections. Still, the play is what matters here. When at the table it’s the next best thing to owning a real machine.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												This is the only current game on PC that simulates actual physical pinball tables, and it does it well.   I highly recommend Pinball Arcade for those "purists" who don't love having a bunch of cartoon characters dancing around the table as you play.  The physics are entertaining but not as accurate as some rabid fans might suggest and I truly hope Farsight further tweaks them.  Occasionally the game will get weird with "helium ball" or super slowdown where everything including sound & music runs and stays at around 1/4 speed.  These things will right themselves after restarting Steam.Another issue on my laptop, which has Intel integrated + Nvidia dedicated graphics, is that Pinball Arcade's configuration utility only recognizes the integrated graphics.  Performance is still fine, but the flipper has about a 1/5 second input lag (really bad for pinball) which can be somewhat alleviated by turning off v-sync.  Hello screen tearing!  On my desktop PC that only has dedicated Nvidia graphics, there is no problem.Hopefully the promised upgrades (already in use on PS4 and Xbone) will be added to Pinball Arcade soon.08/16/2016 Update-  Performance has actually worsened considerably since I first typed this review.  It seems that with every patch, Pinball Arcade has worsening extreme slowdown issues making it unplayable for me.  Both Pinball FX and Zaccaria Pinball are quite smooth but not Pinball Arcade.  I guess I'll have to upgrade to compensate for sloppy programming...

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												The Pinball ArcadeThe Pinball Arcade features exact recreations of the all-time greatest pinball tables from Williams®, Bally®, Stern®, and Gottlieb® together in one game. Every flipper, bumper, sound effect, and display pixel has been painstakingly emulated in astonishing detail! The Pinball Arcade is available for most game consoles, mobile phones, and tablet computers, including the iPhone, iPad, Android Phones and tablets, the Amazon Kindle Fire, as well as the PlayStation3, PS Vita, Xbox 360, and Macintosh.

												Possibly the best Pinball simulator I've ever played with real life pinball tables accurately recreated in virtual form. Many classics are represented here, but their library is still small at the moment. The Steam store page is a little misleading as the actual software is free with only one table included. number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												I think that PA should be subtitled Game of Drains. I've never played pinball tables where the ball drains so frequently. Its almost laugable, or it would be if I hadn't paid for the first three seasons.I've played a number of the real life tables that the PA tables are based on. The accuracy of the physics isn't even close. For example, Taxi - a very enjoyable table in real life. The shots that are challenging in real life are easy in PA, but sometimes the reverse is true. Launching the ball in the PA version is a joke, if you get the hang of it you can max out your score every time. Which tells me there isn't a real physics being used, it is faked, and it isn't faked well.Some tables drain the ball with incredible frequency. Tables like Whirlwind, a table I enjoyed playing and did quite well with  in other versions. I'm sure people who take their pinball really seriously will say I'm just useless at pinball. I'm definitely more of a casual gamer when it comes to pinball, but I shouldn't have to be an expert to enjoy PA. There are a few tables, very few, that are well emulated in PA, tables such as Funhouse.For anyone who is a casual pinball player I would strongly recommend pinball FX2 over PA.

												While it lacks the technical sophistication of Pinball FX, there's history and quality in these tables--tables without which that other game wouldn't exist. number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												Played this game to death on the Vita. I prefer authentic pins over fantasy-ish pins where lots of stuff appear on the table which can't be done on an actual pin (Sierra's 3D Ultra Pinball series, Pinball FX 2, etc), although I still play those pins sometimes. Aside from the Pro Pinball series, TPA is one of the best pinball games I've ever played, especially when you consider all the tables were digitized from actual real tables. That brings me great joy, as I never once went to the arcades when I was younger and thus have never played any of these pins. I am happy there's at least one company out there willing to keep the legacy of pinball alive.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												Great idea to bring back the classic tables at a fairly reasonable per table price when purchased in season packs. Sadly this pinball simulator falls flat due to the lack of good camera angles. The only static top view is an unnaturally low angle to the glass making it difficult to accurate gauge the trajectory of the ball. I am a big fan of pinball, but I am not a fan of this simulator.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												First, of course, as with any pinball simulation, don't expect perfection and don't expect it to outright replace real, physical pinball tables.  There's just no replacing the feel of a real pinball flying around a table with real targets, bumpers, and ramps, imperfections and all.Once you get over that expectation, though, if you have any appreciation for classic pinball at all, you need to pick this up.  It's clear the developers have a deep appreciation for pinball, from the table effects to the challenges and detailed instructions so you can finally see just how each bonus worked on those tables you could never figure out.  Just because it can't be perfect doesn't mean it's not an outright fun nostalgia trip that's cheaper than actually buying and maintaining real pinball tables.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Not a bad game for a time-killer and just to have some fun. The tables wonderfully varied, and the goals are often a good challenge. However, if you really want to get serious about a top score, or completing all the challenges in one go without having to worry about hitting the limit, then you will have to pay for each table. If you are looking for a game to just play around with that is free, and you don't care to much about scores, this is a good game for you. But if you are looking to dominate the game entirely, be prepared to spend some money.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Pinbug Arcade by FarSight Studios features in a sort exact recreations of the all-time greatest pinball tables from Williams®, Bally®, Stern Pinball®, and Gottlieb® together in one record-breaking bugged game. Every menu, input, sound, and game element has been painstakingly bug riddled in astonishing detail.Download now and you’ll get the incredible 15 Go of code errors for not so free! Missing music, camera problem, wrong key press, endless ball search ™, unsaved settings changes, black mirror on ToM (named the best bug of all time by the forum), undetected collisions, crashes, and other great bugs are also available from within this great game. Each month, regular updates will add classic bugged out the hole tables for years to come!Our goal is for the Pinbug Arcade to become the most bugged and uncomprehensive pinball game ever created. Please support us in our efforts to wreck these tables and join the indelible part of FarSight that is bug!

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												The UI is terrible and unsightly, the music and sound effects are of strangely low quality, the graphics are very subpar all across the board, there is only one free table, and to get more tables costs a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton more money than they'd ever be worth. It's absolutely ridiculous. On top of it all, these "exact recreations" of real-life pinball tables (the entire gimmick of this game) are complete let-downs. These tables seem barely realistic at all and the physics and responsiveness are very wonky as well.All in all, it screams ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port job (of a game that was already kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥), and it is a shining example of the free-to-play business model being used shamefully terribly.There are other, better pinball video games out there which, despite not meant to be recreations of real-life licensed tables, nail the feel of pinball better and with night-and-day difference of video game development craft and quality. Go play Zen Pinball or Pokemon Pinball or Sonic Spinball or Metroid Prime Pinball or 3D Pinball for Windows: Space Cadet... Those are all much better pinball games than this. Pinball FX2 and Dream Pinball 3D are some other ones that are actually on Steam as well, and, although I have never played those, odds are that they are much better than The Pinball Arcade here. It honestly wouldn't be that hard a feat to accomplish. This game is an insult.If you want more details and the specifics for how and why The Pinball Arcade sucks and is garbage, this is a pretty spot-on review from another fellow on Steam:http://steamcommunity.com/id/stavrosthewonderchicken/recommended/238260/

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												Most of the tables are a lot of fun although some can be quite frustrating and it does feel like the ball isn't always behaving realistically.The table packs are quite decent and will give you hours and hours of fun.Sound and gfx are all good although it's quite hard to read many of the texts on these tables when playing anything less than 4K. This is however quite understandable since they are all 1-on-1 copies of existing real life tables.Note that 3d vision also works great here. The tables are fully 3d and the depth added by 3d vision is enhancing the experience quite a lot in my opinion.Sadly enough, all of the above is ruined completely by the totally awkward user interface.Some things work ok with keyboard, others don't. Mouse is teleporting all over the place. Keys aren't always responding when (trying to) enter initials. The Enter key itself is hardly ever working correctly unless the mouse is used at least once to perform the same task.Scrolling through a large list of tables is a nightmare since scrollwheel support is as good as nonexistant.. well, they did try and it IS doing something, but not what anyone would expect. So that's even worse than nothing. And on top of that, every time after leaving a table, the list resets back to the top, making you do the whole 'scrolling' part over and over, again and again. I've had more fun reliving some of my nightmares for days or even weeks on a row.While it could have been a fantastic game, the experience is ruined completely by a user interface which is horrendous on an intergalactic scale.And the strangest of it all is, they have promised a new UI about a year ago. I mean a FULL YEAR! And it still isn't there! How hard can it be? Yet, they are releasing table after table. So they are either ignoring all these issues on purpose or they've absolutely no clue about proper UI design.Shameful.

												The Pinball Arcade is quite possibly the best pinball simulation ever made, but unfortunately everything surrounding that simulation from menus to support sorely lacks in competence. Season Two pales in comparison and is inexplicably more expensive. Pro versions and custom balls can and should be ignored.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2015
												Wow, this game has seen ZERO improvements over the original iPad version I played years ago! The graphics are pretty bad (well, tablet quality really), but most importantly the ball physics are seriously off. Is this the best you can do, FarSight? You claim to be the ultimate accurate sim of real-life pinball machines and you can't get the physics down, after years of development? Take a look at the Pro Pinball series which still hasn't been matched in terms of ball physics. What we have here is about as accurate as a real pinball table covered with ice. I've owned and played actual pinball machines for a decade now and I can tell you that the ball should *not* go across the table at 45 degrees when I plunge it from the tip of the flipper. It should go *up*; not to the side! This makes aiming impossible if you're coming from real-life pinball. It's funny, the Future Pinball project had the exact same problem with ball physics. I wonder why...Not to mention the poor and unrealistic sound effects used for the mechanics; these too seem awfully familiar from open source community attempts at pinball simulation from ages ago... you couldn't get a real machine and an audio tech to sample it for you? I've been waiting for a properly simulated real-life pinball machine on PC for as long as I've played pinball, but it seems impossible to do right judging by this effort.From an experienced pinball player in real life: not recommended.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Having played the Android version, I had high hopes for this game. I was not disappointed. The graphics are excellent, the physics are outstanding and there is Xbox 360 controller support so it get high marks on the playability fronts.On the bad side, if you purchase any pinball tables for one platform, it does not translate over to the others. If I had been Farsight here, I would have had the tables connected to the e-mail address and allowed for cross-platform ownwership, but that may be difficult to implement. Not a REALLY big deal for me, but it could be a deal-breaker to others.Oddly enough, when I did the review on Android Play Store, there were three tables that I was hoping would be released: Addams Family, Cyclone and Xenon. And my wush was granted with Season 4. This is such a big thing that, except for original tables made by others, the standbys Visual Pinball/VPMAME and Future Pinball are no longer on my radar.An excellent game indeed.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Models, textures and lighting are Playstation 2 quality. Yes I said Playstation 2. Farsight made a set of these tables for the Playstation 2 for the "Pinball Hall of Fame". They have since ported those same exact models and textures to PC and other platforms without a texture or model facelift. What you have is one of the ugliest modern day pinball simulators ever released in modern day.The production values for this game are cheap and lazy. Farsight chose to make their new tables look exactly like their ported tables from the playstation 2 days in order to make everything look consistantly ugly.This is not the way you treat classic pinball tables. These tables deserve to be remade digitally by a team of competent artists and programmers.If you need to have your pinball fix. Buy zen pinball tables that are high quality or.. save your money and buy the real tables.  The digital recreations don't do justice to these classics.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												I recommend this game with caution.  It's a very novel idea--it allows you to play numerous real life machines in about a 6/10 or 7/10 enviornment.  Why do I rate it so low?  The physics.  The good news is that we're far beyond the early 90s where multiballs just pass through other balls.  The bad news is if you want a 'real' experience, you'd be best to look at the Pro Pinball! series by Empire Interactive from many years ago.Examples of differences between real pinball/this game:  Flippers don't have the same hydraulic movement that they do in real life--many tricks you can do because of the motion of the flipper are altered or not possible (drop catches for one).  The playfields have no dings / scratches / variable friction (Pro Pinball series actually simulates a 'worn in' machine to your liking) so the ball will travel in a pefectly consistent manner.  Flipper power is inconsistent--I've never seen a machine in my life that had flippers so powerful on Star Trek TNG.  There are very very few solid physics simulations on top of good gameplay for pinball machines.  It's basically the group that made monster's fair + the pro pinball series, followed by everyone else.  The pinball arcade belongs in the group of virtual pinball machines I'd definitely consider playing and are better than 75% of those out there, and loosely just as good as another 15%-20%.  It's not that 5% though and that's why I'd not recommend it.  Try it--make sure you're happy with what you're getting before shelling out the dosh.  It's enjoyable and can be a wicked fun night of nostalgia.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												--A Review By Penguincamp--Well, I was planning to go to this Pinball Expo that was near my town, but it was cancelled for some reason. I was pretty upset about that, being a big pinball fan, and that put me right in the mood for this game, which I found just recently. I downloaded it and played it, and this is what I have to say about it.First off, the remaking of each pinball machine is actually pretty impressive. I saw some of my favorites such as "Taxi" "Funhouse" "Gorgar" and "Firepower" and they loooked pretty decent compared to their originals. The sounds from each pinball machine doesn't really have a difference compared to the originals as well. There's not a bad variety of pinball machines either, most of them from the more popular pinball companies (Williams, Gottlieb, Bally, Stern).The gameplay isn't the best, but it's still bearable. Sometimes the timing of the flippers are a bit off, but I'm just going to ignore that, because in most computer/tablet pinball games I've played, the flippers are always a bit off. The pinball itself has pretty good reactions to the flippers and is pretty accurate. On the top left corner they show the screen on the original pinball machine, as well as the match cutscenes, which is a nice touch. Unfortunately, I don't really know if the match sequence works or not, because one time I actually got a match, but it didn't give me a second try or anything like that, but maybe it was because I was in freeplay mode (I'll talk about that in a second). And I don't think there's actually a way to "shoot again", except in the Harley Davidson pinball machine, which is really disappointing, frustrating, and upsetting.But the main reason I don't recommend this is because you can't actually play a full game unless you really suck. They charge you $9 a pinball machine unless you do two things: 1. Buy the Table pack for $30 (with 21 other machines) costing $1.30 a pinball machine; or 2. Play freeplay mode, where you can only play up to a certain score. Nobody's going to pay $1.30 for a SINGLE PINBALL MACHINE, MUCH LESS $9!!!! (If you are going to pay that much I'm sorry if I hurt your feelings or something). If I was in charge of this game, I would probably give people 5 random free pinball machines and charge, I don't know, 50¢ for a pinball machine. MAYBE EVEN 25¢. Unless you love pinball but suck at video games or your a millionaire that loves pinball but just doesn't have enough room in his house to purchase a physical pinball machine, this game really isn't worth your time unless you are starved for pinball so much you will cry your face off unless you get your hands on a pinball machine.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Have a whole lot of love for classic video games and pinball machines and Pinball Arcade has rejuvenated those feelings in a major way. Have bought Seasons 1 and 2 on my Vita, Season 1 on Steam (will get to Season 2 when the budget allows), and have backed all 3 Kickstarter campaigns that have been run. Even though I own a Twilight Zone pin and can play it any time I want to go in the basement it is a blast to fire it up while I'm waiting on something to come through at my desk. Having played plenty on the machine itself I can't say enough good things about how accurately they've recreated the experience and feel digitally, plus everything simply looks beautiful. Between this and Pinball FX2 I'm actually now planning to slowly work on a digital pinball to play it all in style. Having toyed with the emulation scene versions in the past truly has made me appreciate the great work that has gone into this game. If you love pinball this is absolutely the best way to keep it alive and share it with a new generation.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												The problem with this game is the way it's marketed. It has been from the start.Let me be absolutely clear from the start: this is NOT a free to play game. In it's "free" form, you are playing a demo table, and if you want to get down to playing several tables you have to start forking over money - and quite a bit of it, too.The "DLCs" are not additions to a full game, they are the bundles of tables per "season" that you would otherwise have to buy individually. You can play "trials" of tables you haven't bought yet but they will slap you in the face the moment you actually score decently on them (can't finish a game - you're given the choice "buy now or quit playing")i.e.: Free-to-play part = game DEMO. DLC = game.Then, the actual gameplay:The menu system looks like it's been thrown together by amateurs, is very nonresponsive to input, clumsy to navigate, and there is no steam integration whatsoever.The actual simulation is decent, with proper recreations of table layouts and features of the pinball machines offered, although it lacks the responsive feel and proper physics I've seen in other pinball simulations on the PC. You'd think that in 2013, they'd be able to get physics down as accurately as it gets, but no, not in this one.Graphics: very hit and miss; seems the programmers like excessive amounts of bloom lighting, which actually provides a handicap and makes things ugly. Some of the textures used (especially in the surroundings) are simply poor and blurry. Camera angles can be odd, too.All in all, I don't recommend it, even for pinball enthusiasts (I'm one, loved playing the hell out of the real deal, lots of nostalgia looking over the lineup) - it's just too poorly executed with trying to push it as if it was free to play, and simply lacking in what you'd really expect from something with all the big names on them.

content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I Love Pinball games. Arcade, Digital, it doesn't matter I love it all. Unfortunately, this game has graphics so bad you can't make out parts of the machine. There seems to be input lag between pushing the buttons and the flippers working, and It starts you off with only 1 table to play on, making you pay to open up other tables. Now, the pay as you play feature would be fine, except it forces you into buying tables by season, as opposed to choosing individual tables you want in your collection. Given how low quality the graphics are and how poorly this game seems to have been put out, I wouldn't recommend it, even to the Pinball junkie like myself.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												Don't get me wrong, Pinball Arcade is a good game. But I didn't like it for a multitude of reasons:-It took 8 hours to download, so I had the bar set pretty high for the gameplay. All computers differ, but nonetheless, it greatly affected my experience.-I am a completionist, so...that there are 168 achievements is very annoying.-It was glitchy, and when it wasn't, I easily mastered the one Table that is free.-Speaking of which, yes, you read that right, one free table! That's it. Then you have to buy the rest.So, once again, its a great game. It revives old tables and whatnot, but for the reasons listed above, I don't recommend it. It's not so much a waste of money, as it is a waste of time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 1
												I ignored pinball simulation for a long time as I didn't think it could be enjoyably, or accurately replicated on computer for a long time - even games like Pro Pinball didn't sway that view I had.After I finally found the name of a table I only had vague recollections of since I was about 10 years old (F-14 Tomcat) where my overriding memory of the table was the utterly freak manner in which my dad managed to get a ball stuck on a part of the ball launch ramp. On the first credit with this game's replica of F-14 Tomcat, I managed to recreate the exact same ball stick that the machine can't free up itself.  The only way that is possible is if the developers correctly replicated the very subtle misalignment of the ramp and wireframe on the very top part of the ball launch system, and there is no way in Hell that anyone would 'accidentally' replicate that.  That, my friends, is ridiculous attention to detail.Was utterly sold since then.  I now own more tables than I can actually play, and loving every minute of it.  The price of tables seems high but I promise you they are worth it if you have any interest at all in pinball.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Pinball Arcade is very respectable pinball simulation with a great selection of tables spanning all pinball eras, that is growing as you read this. I will focus mainly on the negative points in this review, because if a simulation like this is pulled off well, there really isn't anything to say about "good points", except that the simulation is good, which, generally speaking, it is.Generally speaking, the physics are very good. The ball goes where you expect it to, except in certain situations where you would backhand-flip a ball  that came to a full stop on your flipper; it goes forwards at an angle instead of actually backwards as it should.While some mechanical sounds, like the sounds of Rudy - from "Funhouse" - shifting his eyes or the spinning disks from "Whirlwind" are really nice, others are a bit lacking, like the flippers sounding like those from some child's toy and wire gates making no sound at all. This is rather minor though and you won't really notice it after some time, but a pinball purist might see this as quite objectionable, especially with Pinball FX 2 to compare it to (which has a whole plethora of fine-tuned mechanical sounds for practically everything).The ball might also get stuck after clipping through a wall or rail. This does not happen often and usually the "Attendant" will pick up on it and serve you a new ball. When the Attendant doesn't, however, it is rather stubborn: if you call it through the menu, more often than not, it will say that the ball is not stuck and not do anything, forcing you to quit the table and restart.The camera will move to look at things happening on the table, like the Bride from "Bride of Pin-bot" turning her head. Sometimes though, it moves the camera when there are still balls rolling around, putting your flippers out of view, leaving you in a hopelessly blinded situation which usually has you drain before the camera goes back to normal again.On all other accounts, though, this is a terrific and ever-growing compilation of real-life pinball classics. The major problems of the ball clipping through stuff or the camera looking at things when you need the focus on your flippers might cost you a game or two, but they happen only rarely.Oh, also, if you're playing with an Xinput controller, the analog triggers activate the lower and upper flippers at different depression levels, like in a real table, allowing for advanced multiball strategies. A nice touch!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												For those who enjoyed playing on a pinball  machine as a kid, this game does deliver when it comes to gameplay. I do recommend trying this game out. The only downside is the in game transactions. Yes the game itself is free however to get the additional tables, you must purchase them one by one or as a pack.They do give you one free table. Tales of the Arabian Nights to try out! The way they built back up these tables electronically from their physical originals, is astounding. The replay value is amazing (at least it was for me)! Each table comes with it's own set of achievments and standard goals to accomplish. However if you purchase the pro pack you will get an additional set of goals called "Wizard Goals" that are very advanced and difficult to achieve, after you accomplish the standard goals. Once you complete all the goals, you unlock some special features such as custom balls, unlimited tilt, etc.. Each table also comes with the history of it as well as A FULL explaination of the entire table. From values of bumpers to helping you complete the main goal of the table and achieve the SUPER EXTREEEEEEME JACKPOT! The instructions are very clear and concise, BUT there is A LOT and i mean A LOT of information to go through. Luckily, they separate the instructions into different categories for you to navagate through.The only cons i have are that, sometimes the ball does get stuck and the "call matience (i know i mispelled that)" does not work. Which means that you will have to reset and start over. This can be especially frusturating if you've gotten very far and this happens. That is really the only con i have with this game. I've run into a situation where i can't navigate back to the table menu after a game is over, but that has happened very very very rarely.In conclusion...try the game out and the Arabian Nights table! If you love it! I recommend purchasing Table Pack One Pro to start with! ******IMPORTANT NOTE!******This game is also available on the iPad, iPhone and PERHAPS Android, i really dont know about Android. HOWEVER! If you purchase table pack one on the PC and table pack two on your tablet or mobile device...YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO RESTORE TABLE PACK ONE ONTO YOUR MOBILE DEVICE FROM YOUR PC! The company recognizes this as two COMPLETELY seperate sets of transactions! This means if you want both packs on both devices...you will HAVE to purchase both packs on both devices!That is all!Have a great time!

Posted: December 19, 2015
												This game for me is one of the greatest games of all time and the greatest Pinball game ever created.  But you probably already knew that.  Its simply put real pinball.  Not synthetic made for PC pinball but actual recreations of some of the best pinball tables of all time, and some not so greatest pinball tables.  I have this game on every platform its been released on, including apple ipad and PSV and even going back to when it was on the PS2 as the williams collection.  Great game, real ball physics that make it a blast to play.  I am a pinball fan and even once owned an actual Stern pinball machine Terminator 3, and this game recreates most of the feel of playing real pinball.  Table I want to see added, The Simpsons pinball by Stern.  If you like the silver ball then get this game you wont regret it.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												If you were/are a real life pinball fan, thumbing through all the 'video pinball' options available to you on Steam, THIS is the series you want to invest your time and money in. Pure awesome, ALL real-life  tables you'll recognize from the past and present meticulously mirrored, with alot of care and feel!  5 stars!<edited Jan 2016 for mistakes and continuing enthusiasm for this product>Several years later, and there still is no competition with Pinball arcade in the video pinball market as far as I'm concerned, and very few if any others, that dedicate themselves to actual production machines exclusively. I've played MOST of these tables in real life, and this company is a godsend to those of us who are fond of the genre.I would also recommend this to those who have never played pinball; There is a reason why many/most of these tables, where considered classics, before digitizing them was even a concept.Seriously, try them out. Great company, great fun. most probably also, really wgood option for playing on ones phone or pad, or business travel on laptop with limited video card capability as well.  What are you waiting for? Go grab that Arabian Nights for free, and prepare to be dazzled and wanting more!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												If you love pinball like I do, then guys... THIS is the real deal.Look, I love Zen's contributions to digital pinball as well (and have several of their 3D versions for 3DS in particular)..  but for Steam / PC *THIS* is the one!With beautiful, fully-accurate, 3D (and HD) renderings of classic pinball tables -- and (using a 360 pad at the least, my preferred method of control) the absolutely wonderful and AUTHENTIC FEELING capabilities of FULL analog control over ball launching, paddles, and even knudging (or tilting!) of the table.  Granted, many control options exist of course... but using a 360 gamepad for this is pretty much the closest you can get to true in-home pinball bliss short of owning SEVERAL machines.  Just my opinion!Even just downloading the game for free is worth it for the free play and free tables you DO get.  But beyond that, I myself have only bought *one* season pack of tables (pretty steeply on sale if I recall) and not just myself but even my PARENTS have had hours of enjoyment here -- with no end in sight.  Adding in the relatively nice Steam functionality (trading card drops earned with purchased packs being one), I wholeheartedly recommend this digital pinball GEM.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Each table has been beautifully recreated in full detail, and the weight behind the ball feels very good.Yes, all but one table you have to buy, but there is good reason for this - each new table added goes through the process of purchasing one of the existing tables, restoring it to fully-operational condition, then re-creating each table as accurate as possible in the game's engine, including programming oversights in the original machine (E.G. Being able to run Borg Multiball alongside Q's Challenge in Star Trek: The Next Generation).This game includes well-known classics such as The Addams Family as well as more obscure machines such as Black Rose. I reccomend that you try out each machine individually to get a feel for the table before buying the full version, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												I should have gone to bed 4 hours ago. But I downloaded Pinball Arcade, and here I am now in the wee hours of the night - just like I used to be 20 years ago - playing through all my old favorites: Red & Ted's Roadshow, The Addams Family, Creature From The Black Lagoon. For anyone that has ever fed the coin slot in the 70's, 80's and 90's, Pinball Arcade is a total must have. The simulation of the boards and the ball physics is absolutely flawless, recreating the feel of a real pinball machine for as good as you could ever ask for, and more. And the fact that they have been given access to the original intellectual property has me sighing happily not just with nostalgia but the same joy of playing these games as I once had. As heartbroken as I was at hearing that the pinball industry has essentially ceased to exist, as full of joy was I at pulling the virtual punger and hearing Morticia Addams purr "Welcome honored guest". Well done Farsight Studios... very well done indeed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												When I first stumbled upon this Pinball simulation, my first thought was: "Oh, someone has made another pinball game." Immediately as I launched the game, I realized how mistaken I was. This is no ordinary pinball game. Someone has created THE ultimate pinball simulation! Probably the best pinball simulation ever! Why? Because this is the first time in my life I had the feeling of playing a real pinball table instead of sitting in front of a computer and because these are 1 to 1 copies of original pinball machines. Internally, this game even uses the original firmware that runs on the real pinball machines! These are no fantasy tables that you never could build in reality. No, this just feels real, at least to me. And yes, this game supports portrait mode! There is no ingame option. You have to rotate the screen on the display driver menu and then run the setup of the game to choose the new rotated resolution.What you should know: you don't have to buy a whole season pack as DLC. You can buy each table seperately (as a pack of one to two tables) in-game.

												***update***  ok i played a few tables and started the challenge had a great time.  i racked up something like 160 million on ripleys believe it or not. it took me all day well 5 hours or so taking breaks. i would pause smoke a cig return play more lol. but i saved the game and decided id take a screen shot and omg the score was gone!!! top score just vanished and not something ill likely do again. then i decided to continue the saved challenge game. guess what its gone and is making me start over again. i still recomend this game i am just warning you there is an issue and one that shouldnt be, given the age of this it wont be fixed either. coulda just been a fluke i havent seen this complaint but it happened to me. so youve been warned.***update*** physics of the ball are kinda weird but again about as good or better then most. my only complaint is its hard to trap the ball. no reason not to try this game as the physics are on par or better then any other pinball game. i only wanted to adress this issue because so many complained about it, again if your that anal about pinball go find one in rl and be happy this is a video game and no pinball game in video form will ever have true physics.so i got bored of shooting zoombies and wanted something retro. i looked up zen pinball fx2 and was annoyed at the new tos. then i downloaded pinball arcade and i have to say  it is one of the besst if not the best pinball game ever for pc.i do not understand the negative feedback on this game. of course the physics are not right and will never be right. its being played on a pc where multitudes of things can happen causing slowness ect. the lighting of the tables is just fine and unless your standing over an actual pinball table the view will always be off on some tables its to be expected. so if your that much of a perfectionist go find a real pinball game and play that and stop the negative comments lol. over all this game is in my book 10/10. from  real tables the history of each table to the play and replay ability. of course its not perfect and like i said never will be but this brings it as close as one would want... yes id pull the plunger again

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Pinball is something I was never really interested in, as initially I thought it was just hitting a ball around a table hours on end trying to score points with no real object. I was very wrong and naive to think this as there is a lot to these table than meets the eyes. These pinball tables more specifically the newer ones with the dot matrix display tend to have a lot of missions and trick shots to complete in order to gain a larger amount of points in a quick succession. Though don't be fooled as completing these missions/ojectives are a lot harder than it seems. My favourite table at the moment is Monster Bash, it has a great theme, nice look and the sounds are really great, it has the arcade feel to it. The idea of the Monster Bash is to light every musician on the table to start the Monster Bash multiball. Lighting the musician's instrument requires completion of the mission/mode of that particular musician, e.g. completing Frankenstien's mode will light Frankenstien and his instrument the keyboard. Completing all the musicians and their instruments gives you a wizard mode called Monsters of Rock which is a multiball mode with higher jackpots than the Monster Bash multiball. You can find rulesheets online if you're unsure how each table is to be played. The game has a good replay value as you're always going back to try and improve on highscores and if you have friends who play it, more the reason to be competitive. If you're friends don't play this game you always have the Global Leaderboards to compete with. They are always updating the game with new tables which is good, the developers are active and are continually improving the game. The graphics seem fine, they could be cleaned up in some areas which I can see are improving on the DX11 version. The game has a nice solid feeling to it and does actually feel like a real pinball machine which offers that realism that makes it that more enjoyable. One thing is for sure mastering the technique of `tilting` is highly required if you're going for endurance and points. The good thing about this game is it allows you to trial everthing before you buy it, so I recommend the game as you can try it and if you don't like it, nothing is lost.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												At the time I'm editing this review I've put close to nine hours into playing with Pinball Arcade.   I'm having an absolute blast so far.Honestly, all I cared about with Pinball Arcade was getting the Attack on Mars table.  I adored that game as a kid, and it still rocks as a young adult.  Playing it again is such a delicious rush of nostalgia for me.  Several of the other ones I've tried, Arabian Nights, Star Trek, and Medieval Madness are pretty awesome too.  The attention to detail in recreating these tables is staggering.However, there are some potential drawbacks I've encountered too.   These weren't deal breakers for me, but they might be for others.  First, the choices for camera control are minimal.  This wasn't a problem for me because the default angle of the camera is pretty much what you'd get playing at the arcade.  But compare this to Dream Pinball, for example.  Dream Pinball had six or seven different options.  If I wanted to follow with the ball I could.  If I wanted to the camera facing more directly downwards, I could do that.   If you don't like the default angle with this simulator you're out of luck.  Second, if you want individual pinball machines there are some inconveniences in your way.  I actually did not know that I could buy individual tables at first.  I thought they came in either smaller packs or seasons.  As of right now, I can purchase a single table if I want.  The price is $4.99 for a single table or $7.99 for the pro version which includes additional options.  However, I have to buy this in game with Steam wallet funds.  My guess is that this is because it would be ridiculous creating individual steam pages for the dozens of pinball tables.  A lot of people may not even be aware that they have this option, so keep that in mind.  Also, $4.99 or $7.99 may sound a bit steep for a single table.   I will say that the "pro" option in my opinion is customization that should be available in the base game, not stuff that should be hidden behind a paywall.  If it was just $4.99 for one table, and you could customize it then I think people would be a bit less annoyed about it.   However, I ask you to consider the alternative.  I haven't seen an Attack from Mars machine in YEARS.  I could travel hours to find an arcade that has one, and then pay dollar after dollar.  Or I could shell out $7,000 dollars and have to store and maintain it myself.  Or I could pay a measly $7.99 and have all the customization options and have access to it forever.  All in all, I will unquestionably get my money's worth and then some.  However, it all depends on how badly you're hurting to play any of these tables.  If you buy the season at a discount, which I did, then your average price per table goes down drastically.  I'll probably upgrade the few tables I enjoy the most to pro and pretty much ignore the rest.  The last potential negative point that I will mention is the ball physics.  I personally did not notice anything wrong, but I know that there have been some negative comments about that from people who were experienced with pinball machines.   As an ordinary consumer who just enjoys pinball now and then, I can't really address concerns that hardcore fans might have, so you should probably read a few negative reviews just to get a balanced perspective.  If you're squeamish about trying pinball arcade, then let me set your fears to rest.  You can try Pinball Arcade for free.  When you download the free platform it includes trial version of ALL the tables.   So, all you have to invest up front is enough time to install the game.  Try it out, and find out which tables or seasons might be worth your money.  I'll conclude this interview with a brief and very sincere thank you to the developers.  You have brought a piece of my childhood to life that I'd never expected to get to experience any time soon, if at all.  I really appreciate the work you're doing, and hope to see more familiar machines on your platform.  Now let's kill some Martians!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I've always liked Pinball, but I never play much in real life until recent.  Pinball Arcade is a great way to practice.I appreciate the lack of glare on the playfield's glass, the Xbox 360 controller support, and seeing both the playfield & the backglass's display at the same time.I wish that the game engine made use of the atmospheric effects (e.g. fog), so the objects (e.g. bumpers, flippers, etc.) on top of playfield's flat surface would stand out more.  Sometimes, I find that everything blends together due to union saturation.There are some graphical glitches.  In Scared Stiff, the coffin glitched into a state of rapidly toggling between its open and closed state.So far, season 1's tables are my favorite, but I found a few gems in season 2.  I usually need several complete game sessions on the table before I can get a good sense of the gameplay and whether or not I like a table.  So, it's difficult to discover tables that I like without purchasing them.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												The Addams family pinball machine.You must purchase this table. Be amazed.For anyone who doesn't know what this game is about, these are real pinball tables brought to life. Most people who play pinball do so with reflexes alone (and only occasionally because of the cost), but the real key to success is knowing what to chase and when on the table. Don't know the rules? No problem. Each table comes with a set of instructions on what to do and when to do it. Then, it's up to you to abuse the table, chase the wizard goals, and rack up a high score.There are online leaderboards, challenges, and lots of tables to try and things to do. You will become great at pinball, learn to read tables, and learn to make complicated shots. Solving each table is a rewarding experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Pros:     +Real pinball action and physics:            One of the truest-to-the-real-thing video pinball games I have ever seen.     +Licensed tables from classic designers and manfacturers:            Some of the biggest and best tables I remeber from my youth.  Lots of hours playing Terminator 2 and Theatre Of            Magic.  Great to see them included!     +Golden, Silver, and Modern Age tables:            I'm not a fan of the older tables, but it's nice to see them paid respect.     +Table of the Month is wonderful for try before you buy:            Full access is always a great thing.  BBut, the schedule for it seems random at times.  It's not a solid month.  More            like "Table of the 30-or-so Days".Cons:     -Regular free-trial mode is too short:           Feels like a marketing ploy just to get you hooked on the table.     -Lack of selection of tables:           ...but there are new choices added every month or so it seems.  So, this is only a minor complaint if you can call it           one at all really.     -Prices for tables is too high:           $4.99 is a bit much for one table, but completely worth it for the packages for two tables for the price of one.           There should be more of these to choose from..     -No cloud saves:           It would be nice to take my favorite tabels on the road without having to pay for them twice.  Also, if I want to           transfer it to my laptop or another PC, then it's, "Good bye, highscores."All in all, the pros far outweigh the cons if you're a fan of pinball games or want to reminisce about tables that played instead of going to class.  The tables are true to the originals.  The only thing missing is being able to actualy shake the tables and release the plunger to start the ball in play.  The game controls, which are tight and responsive, work excptionally well whether you use an controller of the mouse and keyboard.  The game has a strong community with many requests and ideas for future tables coming directly from the fans of the game.  For a freemium game, it's worth at least one IAP.  More than likely, you'll make a few more.            8.5/10

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												I've been an avid player of Farsight's pinball games since the original Gottlieb Hall of Fame and I love each one more and more. Pinball Arcade was a huge step forward... you'll never mistake them for a real world table, but they are fun to play and the emulation and rules are usually spot on. There are also far fewer "magical physics" moments (e.g. balls rebounding off slingshots and up steep ramps) than in the previous games. I don't always love the games they choose to reproduce, but they're rarely boring. Play it now, then go out and find some real pinball games and play those too!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												I keep swinging back and forth on whether I like this pinball emulator or not. On the negative side, features that should be included as base content are stupidly paywalled. I'm talking like freely moving the camera around to look at the tables here. You need to buy the more expensive "pro" pack to get that and the operator menu that lets you customize the game. The game can be quite pricey if you want all the tables, but I'm sure licensing them from several different pinball distributors doesn't come cheap, as well as the fact that many newer tables are franchise tie-ins and are probably more expensive to liscense.On the other hand, this software is the best at what it does, which is emulate actual, liscensed pinball tables. Years ago emulating actual pinball tables used to be an unliscensed fan thing, and the emulators available for it were shoddy and burdensome to work wtih.Pinball Arcade works just great. The whole reason I bought table packs for it was so i could improve my scoring on actual tables at the local pinball arcade. It has been an absolutely fantastic tool for that. The game will walk you through how to score on each and every table for it, Which is way better than reading the  card that comes on machines or asking some snotty stuck up  neckbeard at the arcade to explain it to you. Scoring high on pinball can sometimes involve some pretty obscure methods and it is great to have this game explain exactly how it is done.Overall, even though i am angry about the "premium" content that should be included with the regular tables (camera options!), i have had a good amount of fun with this game and it has really helped my scoring, so i am going to have to recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Pinball Arcade is a title that has a lot of things going for it. Classic pinball tables (well mostly from the 80s and 90s) faithfully recreated for so you can enjoy these tables that made pinball a joy to play. There are some truly great tables like Terminator 2: Judgement Day, Haunted House, Centaur and Pin-Bot among others. What's more is that this game helps to preserve these tables for future generations as actual pinball machines get worn out over time and are difficult to maintain due to the mechanics involved.BUT ... then there comes the bad aspects. Mainly, the pricing model. Like Pinball FX2, Pinball Arcade gives you one table for free in the form of Tales of the Arabian Nights which is an awesome table. If you want more tables, you need to pay. When Pinball Arcade first appeared on Steam, the only way to buy tables was through in-game purchases paid with the Steam wallet. It took awhile for Pinball Arcade to release its tables as DLC and only as Season packs. While this is fine and dandy, smaller packs can only be purchased in game. Tables come in standard and "professional" versions. The professional version only offer the advantage of giving access to operator menus and special balls, features that tables for Pinball FX2 offer as standard. And while $30 for 19 or 21 tables is not technically a bad deal, it's a huge amount to ask for as DLC and becomes even more expensive if you decide you'd rather purchase the smaller packs in-game.This version does not use Steamworks natively to keep track of your friends' scores unless you are also logged in with your Farsight account (which I find difficulty in getting to work). This to me was one of the biggest draws about Pinball FX2, being able to easily compare your scores and top your friends' high scores. This is the sort of thing that should have been easy and automatic from the start.The game is technically good and you can try all the tables for free up to a score cap (just like with Pinball FX2) and you can have fun just playing Tales of the Arabian Nights all the time. Unfortunately, this game's backwards pricing model holds the game back. It's far too expensive and the professional versions feel like a scam to me. But it's still a really fun game. If you can look past these flaws, I would say I recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Just like with Pinball FX2, Pinball Arcade is worth a try since you can play one table for free and you can try out some of the other tables for a short amount of time. There is also the added bonus of "free table of the month" where different tables are available to play in full when you select "play trial version".I played FX2 before I played this, so I will probably go into some comparisons with that, so this review might be more helpful for those who have played that one are are wondering if this game is also worth it. I'll start out with the pros:Pros:-Well done recreations of real life pinball tables.-Decent virtual pinball physics (but different feeling than FX2, I'll elaborate later).-Plenty of great, tried and true classic tables to pick from. A few aren't so good but with how many tables there are you will still get your money's worth. I suggest buying them in the packs (and from what I've heard, people are having issues with in game purchases for the Steam version of this game, so you might be best off sticking to the packs).Cons:-Textures and lighting definitely need some improvement (improved lighting for the PS4 version, yet we're still left behind here on the PC).-Though physics are decent, ball can sometimes be a bit too fast and bouncy, sometimes making it all the way up ramps after a bounce that should barely have made it past the ramp entry.-Terrible UI. The menu system looks like it came from a half-broken game from the mid-90's, and it doesn't feel very responsive. Tables are selected from one long list and can't be sorted in any way.-The extra features you get for the "pro versions" of the tables are not worth the extra price. I don't see why anyone should have to pay extra just to have access to the operator menu and a few other minor bells and whistles.Now, a bit more on the physics and the feel of the game. I did a short review for Pinball FX2 a while ago and was perhaps a bit over-zealous calling the physics spot-on. The physics in both these games feel very good, the best I've ever felt in a pinball videogame, but they are both a bit different and reality actually falls right in the middle of the two. If you are used to Pinball FX2 but have never played a real table, I can describe the ball as being a bit "heavy" and it makes flipper catching and gaining control just a bit too easy. In Pinball Arcade, the ball seems to feel a bit "light", sometimes traveling too fast and making some wierd bounces that send it up ramps and into places it normally would never go (yet despite the extra bouncing I almost never see "airballs"). It also makes flipping catching and gaining control a bit more difficult.If you've never played on a real pinball table (or have only played a few times and it was a long time ago or something similar) then this probably won't bother you. However, if you have at least some experience on any of the real life tables in Pinball Arcade then this can become frustrating at times. Balls will bounce into outlanes more than usual and sometimes you'll be struggling to pull off flipper catches that you know you can repeat over and over again in reality. However, this extra difficulty is balanced a bit in the scoring by the fact that the ball might also bounce into places or make it up ramps that might not actually happen in reality.Overall I would recommend this game. It's a solid pinball title that does a decent job recreating real life tables. Just don't expect it to be perfect.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												For those who enjoyed playing on a pinball  machine as a kid, this game does deliver when it comes to gameplay. I do recommend trying this game out. The only downside is the in game transactions. Yes the game itself is free however to get the additional tables, you must purchase them one by one or as a pack.They do give you one free table. Tales of the Arabian Nights to try out! The way they built back up these tables electronically from their physical originals, is astounding. The replay value is amazing (at least it was for me)! Each table comes with it's own set of achievments and standard goals to accomplish. However if you purchase the pro pack you will get an additional set of goals called "Wizard Goals" that are very advanced and difficult to achieve, after you accomplish the standard goals. Once you complete all the goals, you unlock some special features such as custom balls, unlimited tilt, etc.. Each table also comes with the history of it as well as A FULL explaination of the entire table. From values of bumpers to helping you complete the main goal of the table and achieve the SUPER EXTREEEEEEME JACKPOT! The instructions are very clear and concise, BUT there is A LOT and i mean A LOT of information to go through. Luckily, they separate the instructions into different categories for you to navagate through.The only cons i have are that, sometimes the ball does get stuck and the "call matience (i know i mispelled that)" does not work. Which means that you will have to reset and start over. This can be especially frusturating if you've gotten very far and this happens. That is really the only con i have with this game. I've run into a situation where i can't navigate back to the table menu after a game is over, but that has happened very very very rarely.In conclusion...try the game out and the Arabian Nights table! If you love it! I recommend purchasing Table Pack One Pro to start with! ******IMPORTANT NOTE!******This game is also available on the iPad, iPhone and PERHAPS Android, i really dont know about Android. HOWEVER! If you purchase table pack one on the PC and table pack two on your tablet or mobile device...YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO RESTORE TABLE PACK ONE ONTO YOUR MOBILE DEVICE FROM YOUR PC! The company recognizes this as two COMPLETELY seperate sets of transactions! This means if you want both packs on both devices...you will HAVE to purchase both packs on both devices!That is all!Have a great time!

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												I've always liked Pinball, but I never play much in real life until recent.  Pinball Arcade is a great way to practice.I appreciate the lack of glare on the playfield's glass, the Xbox 360 controller support, and seeing both the playfield & the backglass's display at the same time.I wish that the game engine made use of the atmospheric effects (e.g. fog), so the objects (e.g. bumpers, flippers, etc.) on top of playfield's flat surface would stand out more.  Sometimes, I find that everything blends together due to union saturation.There are some graphical glitches.  In Scared Stiff, the coffin glitched into a state of rapidly toggling between its open and closed state.So far, season 1's tables are my favorite, but I found a few gems in season 2.  I usually need several complete game sessions on the table before I can get a good sense of the gameplay and whether or not I like a table.  So, it's difficult to discover tables that I like without purchasing them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Pinball Arcade is not a Pinball game, it's a pinball simulator. Farsight studios purchase historical and prestige pinball machines and the rights to publish them, pull the electronics and mechanics apart, and stick them into a video game, exactly how they are portrayed in real life. If you're a fan of pinball, either video or in real life, you'll love Pinball Arcade, there really is nothign else on par for realism. That said, potential downsides are the user interface for PC, as well as price for entry. you really do have to buy a season pack to start enjoying.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												Great recreations of great tables in this game. There's some issues - the graphics could use some work, and the playfield textures in particular are pretty fuzzy in some places. (An update to the game in early 2014 will hopefully improve on this.) Decent physics engine, but the flippers are a bit wonky (really comes to light when trying to perform advanced maneuvers, like cradle seperations). Several tables seem to be intentionally made a bit easier than they would be in reality, so that you can get longer games going, though whether that's a good thing or a bad thing is really up to whoever's playing.But, overall, everything plays well and you can have a lot of fun playing good pinball. Detailed rulesheets for each table, alongside simple starting goals to accomplish, will let you understand what's going on farily easily on most games. There's some online leaderboards, and upcoming tournaments and head-to-head challenges, to scratch the competitive itch. And, well, you're playing some classics of arcade gaming, for sure!Fair warning, you only get two tables for free at any time: Tales of the Arabian Nights (which is worth the download on its own, excellent table) and a rotating ad-supported Table of the Month. Other tables come in packs of 1 or 2, or in Season packs of about 20 tables each. My personally recommended table packs: All of Season One, White Water / Space Shuttle, Champion Pub / Whirlwind, Terminator 2. Never, ever play Goin' Nuts or Class of 1812.

												If you ever had an old favourite real world pinball machine (from the first to the last), this aims to recreate them all, table by table!P.A is free, with one table free, and you pay microtransactions to get each new one (about $3 - not bad when you know that it was $1 to $2 a game on the real deal!), with "Seasons" of tables added to every so often.(Three Seasons now, S3 just started.)There's some big names too. Star Trek TNG, T2, Elvira's two pinball machines and many you may not know (same as me) but will enjoy anyway (same as me)!(Bride of Pinbot, Medival Madness and Tales of Arabian Nights are pretty challenging! And the last one is the free starter machine!)And all machines you can try for free until you hit a certain score (which stops play).You can also customise the ball among more things!And all I needed was a simple Core2Duo!AND it's controller enabled, and works great! Using XBOX360 controller, triggers for flippers, left stick to bump the table, A to use the plunger (or right stick for older "pull the stick" style ones!).HIGHLY recommended!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I love Pinball Arcade. So many great tables are here. I actually have more fun playing TBA than playing real tables. The real thing is usually broken, the sound is turned off, or it's in an location where there's too much glare or you can't hear anything.The physics are pretty good, except it seems a little slower than in real life and it's really hard to hit the far left and right lanes on some tables. Using an xbox controller works great. It defaults to the analog triggers where you can hold it halfway to activate just the lower flippers, and pull the trigger further to activate the upper flippers. This allows you to be able to capture and hold balls with a flipper while actively using other flippers during multiball. But you can always change the setting to the bumpers if you prefer that. Xbox controllers are preferred because you have that digital/analog choice as opposed to PS3/4 types of controllers with their purely analog buttons.The DLC isn't that bad $30 gets you tens of tables depending on which season you buy. Seasons 1 and 2 have more tables because the development costs have already been offset by sales of console titles Pinball Hall of Fame: The Williams Collection and by the Kickstarters for Star Trek, Twilight Zone, and Terminator (pleeeease bring us Adams Family!!!).I know in Season 3 they had Diner, Cyclone, and Earthshaker in the works. The plebs voted for Diner so I don't think I'll see my favorite table Earthshaker in 2014 :(Anyway, love this game. It's well worth it on PC since you can rotate your monitor 90 degrees and play in portrait mode. There's no "cabinet mode" yet, but they said they're working on it.
