content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												This is what I reach for when I want to play pinball. I've purchased it on several platforms and the PC is easily the best experience of all of them.They absolutely nailed the physics for playing the machines. About the only thing that's missing is the physical interaction you get playing with a real table.What works for this, is that they've selected many of the best pinball machines that have ever been made. This leaves out the trial and error of developing new tables and lets them focus on programming the experience of playing the machine.If there's any complaint, it's the price of each table. Then I think about how many quarters I spent on many of these machines over the years and the price of the table suddenly seems to be a pittance. Reading their blog, I've also learned about the costs of licensing each of these tables (Addams Family nearing the end of development and they couldn't reach an agreement with Christopher Lloyd to use his likeness on the machine... will be interesting to see what they do).With all of the challenges that are presented for each table, I'm happy that I spent the money on this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I absolutely love The Pinball Arcade! It is my favorite pinball simulator video game yet made. I love that it provides reasonably faithful reproductions of real pinball tables. The value is good at 10-20 games a season, $30 a season for the base model, $40 a season for all of the tables with access to the operator's menu and some other minor bonuses. That works out to between $1.50 and $4 a table  That's a really good deal if you can't afford that price of a physical pinball table collection or don't have the space for them. You can also buy the tables individually if you don't want to buy them all, though the price per table is somewhat higher that way. You start out with one pinball table, Tales of the Arabian Nights, without paying a cent. You can play that table as much as you want (no access to the operator's menu though). You can also try out other tables for free, but you can only play until you reach a certain score, which I believe is the lowest score to get on the in table high score board. You can use the free table and the trials on other tables to practice your basic pinball skills before you start investing in full tables or season sets.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 8, 2014
												Remember when you could go to a bar, restaurant, mall, or convenience store and find tucked away a shining, blinking machine with a presence that was just begging to eat a fist full of quarters?  Sadly, this experience is dying.  However, for years now this pinball collection has been gathering pieces of gaming history which are falling into disrepair.  While there are other great pinball games on the market, Farsight is preserving these gems that we have actually touched, felt, and had that special shiver when the loud free game knock slapped at your fingertips.Pricey?  I'll admit that.  But I'm willing to spend it if it means that we can preserve digitally this piece of arcade history that we can't simply back up on a thumb drive of ROMs.  And if it helps at all, you always have two tables to play, the fun Arabian Nights and whichever machine is the table of the month.  Just try it and see.  We'll make wizards of you all yet.

content:

												This game is a dream come true. I absolutely love the Star Trek: The Next Generation table, playing it whenever I could in high school, so the Season One table pack was a must buy for me. As someone who can't afford a real table yet, these collections of famous and historical tables is an incredible value. Plus, they take up MUCH less space in the house!Edit: After playing for a while longer, I wanted to update my review with a caveat. I still love the game, and find it a beautiful recreation of the physical tables...but...it is occaisinally buggy, and the dev team doesn't seem to deploy fixes very often. I have only run into one game breaking bug on one table (Funhouse), but other, smaller bugs which have been identified by the community, remain in the game (looking at you, Arabian Nights top skill shot).The tables are expensive and don't seem to go on sale very often. If you like pinball, however, and can put up with a few bugs and long times for patches, then it's worth an install - at least for the free table.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Pinball Arcade is very respectable pinball simulation with a great selection of tables spanning all pinball eras, that is growing as you read this. I will focus mainly on the negative points in this review, because if a simulation like this is pulled off well, there really isn't anything to say about "good points", except that the simulation is good, which, generally speaking, it is.Generally speaking, the physics are very good. The ball goes where you expect it to, except in certain situations where you would backhand-flip a ball  that came to a full stop on your flipper; it goes forwards at an angle instead of actually backwards as it should.While some mechanical sounds, like the sounds of Rudy - from "Funhouse" - shifting his eyes or the spinning disks from "Whirlwind" are really nice, others are a bit lacking, like the flippers sounding like those from some child's toy and wire gates making no sound at all. This is rather minor though and you won't really notice it after some time, but a pinball purist might see this as quite objectionable, especially with Pinball FX 2 to compare it to (which has a whole plethora of fine-tuned mechanical sounds for practically everything).The ball might also get stuck after clipping through a wall or rail. This does not happen often and usually the "Attendant" will pick up on it and serve you a new ball. When the Attendant doesn't, however, it is rather stubborn: if you call it through the menu, more often than not, it will say that the ball is not stuck and not do anything, forcing you to quit the table and restart.The camera will move to look at things happening on the table, like the Bride from "Bride of Pin-bot" turning her head. Sometimes though, it moves the camera when there are still balls rolling around, putting your flippers out of view, leaving you in a hopelessly blinded situation which usually has you drain before the camera goes back to normal again.On all other accounts, though, this is a terrific and ever-growing compilation of real-life pinball classics. The major problems of the ball clipping through stuff or the camera looking at things when you need the focus on your flippers might cost you a game or two, but they happen only rarely.Oh, also, if you're playing with an Xinput controller, the analog triggers activate the lower and upper flippers at different depression levels, like in a real table, allowing for advanced multiball strategies. A nice touch!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												The pictures honestly do not do this game justice. The tables, colors, and sounds are recreated perfectly. Everything looks, sounds and plays pretty much like the actual tables I remember playing back in the day. The only thing is, I don't remember the actual tables being so "fast" and thus it throws off the timing I was used to a little bit. It's almost like the back legs are a quarter to half inch too high, so it's not by much, if they were able to slow the ball down by 3-5%, it'd be perfect. When it comes to paying for tables, you can buy the tables individually through the program at $4.99 for the standard or $8.99 for the pro, some even come packaged with another table. That's actually fairly cheap considering I used to drop at least that much (usually WAY more) playing them in arcades, bowling alleys, and bars in just one visit. So before dropping the $30-$40 bucks on the season packs, take a look at which tables you want in the program itself and see what the price is individually. Overall, I am VERY pleased with being able to replay these tables again on the PC with such perfection and attention to detail, and other then a minor tweak on the speed of the tables, there's nothing I would change. The creators of this program and the people that contribute to it know their tables and should be very proud of what they have accomplished, you guys (and gals) nailed it.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												As far as pinball sims on the market, or even pinball games in general, there has never been a more accurate representation of playing pinball in real life than The Pinball Arcade. It's the closest you'll get to real life pinball, and with a great selection of tables (with more coming out all the time), you're sure to find something you remember from your childhood within. Farsight's had their fair share of bumps on the road, but they've made up for it with heart and their pure love of the game. Tales of the Arabian Nights is free, so unless you hate fun, I can't suggest this game any higher.

												Everything about the game just feels like it works perfectly, from the recreation of the tables to the sound effects to the physics and ball movement, its very difficult to fault much except for player error when losing a ballComing from the Android version on a tablet to the PS Vita and PS3 version i can happily say with each update this version is quickly becoming the better and will probably only be in competition with the PS4 versionMy only gripe is that the tables are sold through the game itself, the only steam sale options are £23 and £30 for a basic table pack per season, and £30 and £40 for the pro table packs per season, and each table is purchasable through the game itself, while it can seem a lot of money, i've paid more for digital gaming that i havent even used half as much as the basic free content of this one, Comparisons with Pinball FX 2 are common to see as it's the other major leading game in this genre, however they are both, from my experience, extremely different games, not saying that either is better than the other, I personally feel that the "real" tables and tighter feel to the physics makes this game my choice...

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												The Addams family pinball machine.You must purchase this table. Be amazed.For anyone who doesn't know what this game is about, these are real pinball tables brought to life. Most people who play pinball do so with reflexes alone (and only occasionally because of the cost), but the real key to success is knowing what to chase and when on the table. Don't know the rules? No problem. Each table comes with a set of instructions on what to do and when to do it. Then, it's up to you to abuse the table, chase the wizard goals, and rack up a high score.There are online leaderboards, challenges, and lots of tables to try and things to do. You will become great at pinball, learn to read tables, and learn to make complicated shots. Solving each table is a rewarding experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												Before I say anything nice, I have to voice that I am VERY irritated with the people who make this.  I bought it a year or two, back on XBOX 360, and every table pack they released.. the problem is, they only released 3 or 4, then stopped.. while the content kept coming on the PSN store.  I don't care why, but it REALLY sucks I had to pay for stuff twice, just to be able to get an up-to-date version.  That being said, if you have never bought this before, it is REALLY good (I own every table released by Zen Pinball on XBOX, but I really like how these are authentic tables.. ones I actually played growing up).  Zen Pinball has the edge as far as overall performance and presentation, but this is not far off at all.  Despite my jaded perspective towards feeling like the developer's screwed me, I HIGHLY recommend this.  At least get it for free while you can still get a free table (and a pretty decent one from the pick) and see for yourselves.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												Pros:     +Real pinball action and physics:            One of the truest-to-the-real-thing video pinball games I have ever seen.     +Licensed tables from classic designers and manfacturers:            Some of the biggest and best tables I remeber from my youth.  Lots of hours playing Terminator 2 and Theatre Of            Magic.  Great to see them included!     +Golden, Silver, and Modern Age tables:            I'm not a fan of the older tables, but it's nice to see them paid respect.     +Table of the Month is wonderful for try before you buy:            Full access is always a great thing.  BBut, the schedule for it seems random at times.  It's not a solid month.  More            like "Table of the 30-or-so Days".Cons:     -Regular free-trial mode is too short:           Feels like a marketing ploy just to get you hooked on the table.     -Lack of selection of tables:           ...but there are new choices added every month or so it seems.  So, this is only a minor complaint if you can call it           one at all really.     -Prices for tables is too high:           $4.99 is a bit much for one table, but completely worth it for the packages for two tables for the price of one.           There should be more of these to choose from..     -No cloud saves:           It would be nice to take my favorite tabels on the road without having to pay for them twice.  Also, if I want to           transfer it to my laptop or another PC, then it's, "Good bye, highscores."All in all, the pros far outweigh the cons if you're a fan of pinball games or want to reminisce about tables that played instead of going to class.  The tables are true to the originals.  The only thing missing is being able to actualy shake the tables and release the plunger to start the ball in play.  The game controls, which are tight and responsive, work excptionally well whether you use an controller of the mouse and keyboard.  The game has a strong community with many requests and ideas for future tables coming directly from the fans of the game.  For a freemium game, it's worth at least one IAP.  More than likely, you'll make a few more.            8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Pinball Arcade is currently the only multi-platform pinball simulation that emulates actual pinball machines as opposed to fictional ones. A solid variety of machines from manufacturers Gottlieb, Bally, Williams, and Stern (Data East and Sega to be included) are present with over 40 machines ranging from the Electro-Mechanical machines of the 1960's all the way to modern Stern machines of the current millenium. When you download TPA (which is a free client/platform), you get the table "Tales of the Arabian Nights" free of charge, with the rest of the tables free to try out until you purchase them either in bulk season packs or in individual 2-packs (individual packs being in-app only as of now). While the game hasn't been launched with EVERY feature intended, the developers are looking to add more features alongside more monthly tables such as more gamemodes, physics fixes, and graphical enhancements.Overall if you're a fan of real pinball machines, than this is certainly the game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Each table has been beautifully recreated in full detail, and the weight behind the ball feels very good.Yes, all but one table you have to buy, but there is good reason for this - each new table added goes through the process of purchasing one of the existing tables, restoring it to fully-operational condition, then re-creating each table as accurate as possible in the game's engine, including programming oversights in the original machine (E.G. Being able to run Borg Multiball alongside Q's Challenge in Star Trek: The Next Generation).This game includes well-known classics such as The Addams Family as well as more obscure machines such as Black Rose. I reccomend that you try out each machine individually to get a feel for the table before buying the full version, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I love Pinball Arcade. So many great tables are here. I actually have more fun playing TBA than playing real tables. The real thing is usually broken, the sound is turned off, or it's in an location where there's too much glare or you can't hear anything.The physics are pretty good, except it seems a little slower than in real life and it's really hard to hit the far left and right lanes on some tables. Using an xbox controller works great. It defaults to the analog triggers where you can hold it halfway to activate just the lower flippers, and pull the trigger further to activate the upper flippers. This allows you to be able to capture and hold balls with a flipper while actively using other flippers during multiball. But you can always change the setting to the bumpers if you prefer that. Xbox controllers are preferred because you have that digital/analog choice as opposed to PS3/4 types of controllers with their purely analog buttons.The DLC isn't that bad $30 gets you tens of tables depending on which season you buy. Seasons 1 and 2 have more tables because the development costs have already been offset by sales of console titles Pinball Hall of Fame: The Williams Collection and by the Kickstarters for Star Trek, Twilight Zone, and Terminator (pleeeease bring us Adams Family!!!).I know in Season 3 they had Diner, Cyclone, and Earthshaker in the works. The plebs voted for Diner so I don't think I'll see my favorite table Earthshaker in 2014 :(Anyway, love this game. It's well worth it on PC since you can rotate your monitor 90 degrees and play in portrait mode. There's no "cabinet mode" yet, but they said they're working on it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												The pictures honestly do not do this game justice. The tables, colors, and sounds are recreated perfectly. Everything looks, sounds and plays pretty much like the actual tables I remember playing back in the day. The only thing is, I don't remember the actual tables being so "fast" and thus it throws off the timing I was used to a little bit. It's almost like the back legs are a quarter to half inch too high, so it's not by much, if they were able to slow the ball down by 3-5%, it'd be perfect. When it comes to paying for tables, you can buy the tables individually through the program at $4.99 for the standard or $8.99 for the pro, some even come packaged with another table. That's actually fairly cheap considering I used to drop at least that much (usually WAY more) playing them in arcades, bowling alleys, and bars in just one visit. So before dropping the $30-$40 bucks on the season packs, take a look at which tables you want in the program itself and see what the price is individually. Overall, I am VERY pleased with being able to replay these tables again on the PC with such perfection and attention to detail, and other then a minor tweak on the speed of the tables, there's nothing I would change. The creators of this program and the people that contribute to it know their tables and should be very proud of what they have accomplished, you guys (and gals) nailed it.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Fun fact about Farsight Studios, they created one of the most infamous games of all time, action 52 (the genesis version anyway). Most of their back catalog, while not quite as bad, isn't great either, filled with shovelware such as backyard football/baseball and game party 1/2/3 for the wii. Pinball Arcade however, is quite simply a masterpiece. They first started making pinball sims with Pinball Hall of Fame: The Gottleib collection in 2004, and have spent the decade since refining their pinball recreations. There is no better pinball sim on the market, it's almost as good as owning the actual tables.It's a bit pricey at 150 bucks for all the tables (bear in mind thats something like 50+ tables), but it's worth it, and considering i've probably spent at least 5 times that playing pins at arcades and bars over the years with nothing to show but memories it's a steal as far i'm concerned, and hey you get the first one free. I own all the tables on my nexus, most of them on ps3, and now that it's on steam i'll be buying them all again (i'm hoping to set up a virtual pinball table at some point).Try the free table (2 technically since theres a table thats free to play each month), and if your any kind of pinball fan i'm willing to bet you won't be able to stop yourself from buying more.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
Edit: Rescinded my recommendation due to the way this game manages achievements. If you sample the free trial, it will mar your achivements stats until you purchase and play all the DLC. If you're a completionist, you should browse the prices in the store to decide whether that's worth it to you.This is only about the free "Arabian Nights" table.  I can't say whether the experience with one table extends to the others."Arabian Nights" is a solid pinball simulation.  If you like that sort of thing, you won't be disappointed.  The physics are good.  Camera tracking is good.  The animation is smooth, even when other programs are running.I expected to get 40+ hours of play from this free table, but it was only about 12.  Other tables will probably be a mixed bag.  Some of them, especially the older ones, are much simpler games.The target demographic is obviously "dudes with nostalgia and disposable cash".  The menu music is generic rock.  True to period, the free table includes a female voice that drips with innuendo.  There's a lot of DLC, which adds up to an expensive game by Steam standards.  If you need to justify it, remind yourself how much real pinball machines cost.Usability and user experience have some glaring problems.Customization options are a bit thin.  If there is a way to remap the nudge keys, I haven't found it yet.  Is there a way to check or change the screen resolution?  I didn't see it.There are achievements!  They're stupid, and I hate them.  Imagine: You're doing really well.  You've gotten into a good rhythm, and the ball's racking up points all over the place.  Suddenly a congratulatory popup appears!  It uses Distraction!  It's super effective!Fortunately, like this review, they eventually run out so you can get back to playing.About the achievements: The base game seems to include them all, but to actually achieve them will require you to purchase all the DLC. If you value your achievement statistics, price out all the DLC before even trying this.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												With the release of the unfinished/rough new UI FarSight has continued in its tradition of half-assing things and perpetuating their poor communication. They had this new UI in beta for 6+ months, but didn't bother to implement many, if any, of the suggestions from the testers. Nor did they bother to fix many of the game breaking bugs, fix any of the long outstanding bugs on many of the tables, or deliver on promises that were made over the last 3 years.This new UI isn't the be all to end all of things, but it does create a situation where the game iself is now in a state that comes close to unplayable. From extreme frame rate drops due to annoying banner notifications, to a continuation of the settings etc not saving unless you actually finish a game right through to the end first. The annoyances and bugs that interfere with the ability to actually finish a game with no glaring, in your face, bugs is getting less and less likely.This new UI is like the welcome mat for all players, new and old, that come to this product. It is time for FarSight to decide if they want to make a choice to aliente their entire customer base and continue on the path path of bad decisions, or merely make a few of them slightly diapointed and take the opportunity to fix things by slowing down their release schedule a bit. They have stated numerous times that their costs are so tight that they cannot take so much as a week off to spend time to fix things after it has been released, but if they don't this debacle may signify the end of TPA due to the erroneous decision to force an unfinished product out.Original Review:Get yer nostalgia on with true pinball tables re-created in The Pinball arcade. This is the best pinball simulator for the pinhead you know. Learn rulesets on real world machines for a fraction of the cost in arcades, and have access to some rare games that are difficult to find outside of museums, private collections or conventions.Be aware that even though this is listed under Free to Play you get a single tables free, but the rest of the tables are al a carte or you can buy season passes to buy in groups for a discounted rate.

												New user interface makes it very difficult to see what games you have bought. Where before it was possible to see if you had done the pinball table challenges at a glance, now it requires clicking the pinball game. There is an option to sort by achievements, but it's still not visible until you click the game.When starting a game, the interface graphics at the bottom show which premium pinballs you have purchased. Fortunately, you can turn the music off in the user interface.Old review from December 2014:Faithful simulation of many classic pinball games.The games are faithful to the original tables, right down to the rage-inducing outer lanes. Although physical is much nicer (and no lag), these are a great substitute if you don't have space for the real thing. Rarely have I seen a difference between the simulation and the real table.Sounds and graphics are sufficient for modern computers. I would appreciate higher resolution scans for some of the table surfaces.You can buy access to single games as DLC (usually $5), or purchase a whole pack. The season packs have some dud playfields -- be patient and wait for a sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												TL;DR is in front, 'cause I plan on writing a novel:This game has really good (but not exactly true to life) physics, graphics are pretty good in dx11, and the tables are painstaking recreations of their real life counterparts. Outside of the actual gameplay, everything is awful; interface is clunky, changing settings can be frustrating and inconsistent, prices are crazy high and feel content locked (you have to pay more to get the "pro mode" tables, which allows you to change table settings). To boot, updates are rare, and FarSight has had consistent troubles which causes releases to be slow.Still the best sim on steam though, which makes it easy to recommend. Particullarly because the free table is Tales of the Arabian Nights, which is one of the better tables out there.On to the full review.....The pros!Of the pinball sims I've played, this game has the most realistic physics. Ball behavior is consistent, and you can do a lot of tricks that are possible in real life like ball transfers. When I've missed a shot, it always felt like it was because I messed up the shot, rather than getting robbed by the game itself. The speed of the games feel mostly right, and on the tables I've played, all the field bits behaved like they should've.This game consists of tables that are painstakingly recreated from real life tables, and has a decent selection of tables. As a result, duds are far less common, and the tables that aren't the most fun to play are typically there because they were significant to the history of pinball in some way. The most notable example of this is the Black Hole table which isn't the most fun to play today, but back when it was introduced it was revolutionary.In properly configured DX11, this game looks really damn good. Lighting can be a tad strange sometimes, but otherwise the tables look great.The free table is fantastic. Tales of the Arabian Nights, although a bit one dimensional, has one of the best wizard modes in all of pinball. Theres a lot of play to be had on it, it's a good table to learn how to play on, and overall just flows really well. Makes the game well worth the download by itself, in my opinion.The Eh.....A common problem amonst pinball games is present here, and that's camera angles. To me there just wasn't really a "best view." All of them felt a little weird, although I feel there's enough camera options that everyone could find a view that they like.The physics, although great, aren't true to life. Sometimes flippers don't feel quite right. The ball doesn't do unexpected things sometimes, like pop up, or just do an off kilter bounce. All of these tables are "brand new" so they won't have the breaking in or "features" that most of these 20 to 30 year old tables will have. Sorely absent is the "feel" of the table; the flipper flipping, the table shaking from stuff happening, pressing the buttons and pulling the plunger, and handling the table in general.If you aren't using DX11, or have it configured improperly, the game looks very lackluster.The bad stuff. :( Nudging in this game just doesn't feel good. Rather than a bump, it feels like you're taking a sledge to the table. It manages to fullfill it's purpose most of the time, but if you are used to doing finer control like little bumps and such, this will bother you to no end. The interface is terrible, and feels tacked on. Navigating the menus is cumbersome and changing settings is frustrating. I've changed settings, and had them change back for absolutely no reason. This game has the worst DLC integration I've seen, short of the little phone games designed to trick you into purchasing things. In game, the only way to purchase tables and packs is by using your steam wallet, which in turn can only have funds added to it in set amounts. Why they utilze this rather than allowing you to purchase content using your account information mystifies me.Pricing for this game is also pretty bad. Granted, I can't imagine getting the licsenses to reproduce these tables was cheap, and the work going into recreating them couldn't have been easy, but it feels like I'm getting gouged, for a couple of reasons. The first, is that you can't buy individual tables; you have to buy tables in either packs of two, which usually consists of one good table, and one meh table, or whole seasons, which may have a whole pile of tables you like, alongside a bunch you'll never touch. The second, is the "pro pack" versus the "table pack." If you want to access the operators menu, and make the table behave like a tournament table, you have to buy the pro pack, which is more expensive than the table pack. Besides that, there is no other difference between the them, which is what makes it feel like a price gouge. You literally have to pay more to access a menu, which isn't even available on every table. That's it. And it frustrates me to no end.As far as I know, there's no cross buying for tables. If you want to play a table you own on the PC version on your tablet, you'll have to rebuy it, which just sucks.All that aside, this is still the best sim out there. The bad stuff can be really off putting, but once you get into the actual game it plays like a dream.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												If you're a lover of real pinball machines, Pinball Arcade stands alone.  Previously the only real option to play your old favorite tables was to use Visual Pinball in conjunction with PinMame.  It was 2D only, buggy, and relied on support from user created tables.  Pinball Arcade is exceptional in every way except for the fact that newer tables have poorly recorded sound.  It literally sounds like someone held up a microphone to a real pinball machine.  Adequate, but not as good as the emulated sound output from PinMame.  Also, not all tables allow you to access in game settings like those found in real machines.  Still, one can only hope that someday every pinball machine ever made will be included in Pinball Arcade.  Nothing else comes close to preserving a great part of gaming history.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The Pinball Arcade is currently the only multi-platform pinball simulation that emulates actual pinball machines as opposed to fictional ones. A solid variety of machines from manufacturers Gottlieb, Bally, Williams, and Stern (Data East and Sega to be included) are present with over 40 machines ranging from the Electro-Mechanical machines of the 1960's all the way to modern Stern machines of the current millenium. When you download TPA (which is a free client/platform), you get the table "Tales of the Arabian Nights" free of charge, with the rest of the tables free to try out until you purchase them either in bulk season packs or in individual 2-packs (individual packs being in-app only as of now). While the game hasn't been launched with EVERY feature intended, the developers are looking to add more features alongside more monthly tables such as more gamemodes, physics fixes, and graphical enhancements.Overall if you're a fan of real pinball machines, than this is certainly the game for you.

												Everything about the game just feels like it works perfectly, from the recreation of the tables to the sound effects to the physics and ball movement, its very difficult to fault much except for player error when losing a ballComing from the Android version on a tablet to the PS Vita and PS3 version i can happily say with each update this version is quickly becoming the better and will probably only be in competition with the PS4 versionMy only gripe is that the tables are sold through the game itself, the only steam sale options are £23 and £30 for a basic table pack per season, and £30 and £40 for the pro table packs per season, and each table is purchasable through the game itself, while it can seem a lot of money, i've paid more for digital gaming that i havent even used half as much as the basic free content of this one, Comparisons with Pinball FX 2 are common to see as it's the other major leading game in this genre, however they are both, from my experience, extremely different games, not saying that either is better than the other, I personally feel that the "real" tables and tighter feel to the physics makes this game my choice...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												Extremely fun pinball simulator.  Pinball Arcade has the licenses that make playing these tables a great reminder of what it was like to experience the physical tables, if you've had the privilege.The latest patch features portrait mode support, which is a welcome addition (in spite of the occasional bugginess).  It is rumored that future patches will add DirectX11 support, with the low ambient light mode that the PS4 version features - as well as second monitor support to display the back glass!  Great things to look forward, along with more great licenses.  Perhaps even the conspicuously missing Addams Family (which has severe licensing entanglements) - fingers crossed!On the negative side, some tables are still somewhat buggy - with balls occasionally popping through the table, or flippers - even launching off in to space!  Mysterious lag plagues some tables as well, which really affects the physics; making the tables feel extra bouncy, even "spongy."  I find it easy to forgive these occasional glitches, and wait for patches that should improve the quality of the simulation.  I experienced a similar upgrade it quality across patches on the XBox - and I gladly repurchased these tables on the PC.Pinball FX2 does come across as more polished altogether - their tables are designed specifically for the computer screen, and they benefit from it.  Very little bugginess there, beautiful visuals, seamless portrait support, excellent social support, and polished menus.  I find that both are worth owning for the true pinball fanatic (as I am), since they each have their strengths - and I wouldn't want to be without either experience!

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Fun fact about Farsight Studios, they created one of the most infamous games of all time, action 52 (the genesis version anyway). Most of their back catalog, while not quite as bad, isn't great either, filled with shovelware such as backyard football/baseball and game party 1/2/3 for the wii. Pinball Arcade however, is quite simply a masterpiece. They first started making pinball sims with Pinball Hall of Fame: The Gottleib collection in 2004, and have spent the decade since refining their pinball recreations. There is no better pinball sim on the market, it's almost as good as owning the actual tables.It's a bit pricey at 150 bucks for all the tables (bear in mind thats something like 50+ tables), but it's worth it, and considering i've probably spent at least 5 times that playing pins at arcades and bars over the years with nothing to show but memories it's a steal as far i'm concerned, and hey you get the first one free. I own all the tables on my nexus, most of them on ps3, and now that it's on steam i'll be buying them all again (i'm hoping to set up a virtual pinball table at some point).Try the free table (2 technically since theres a table thats free to play each month), and if your any kind of pinball fan i'm willing to bet you won't be able to stop yourself from buying more.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												With the release of the unfinished/rough new UI FarSight has continued in its tradition of half-assing things and perpetuating their poor communication. They had this new UI in beta for 6+ months, but didn't bother to implement many, if any, of the suggestions from the testers. Nor did they bother to fix many of the game breaking bugs, fix any of the long outstanding bugs on many of the tables, or deliver on promises that were made over the last 3 years.This new UI isn't the be all to end all of things, but it does create a situation where the game iself is now in a state that comes close to unplayable. From extreme frame rate drops due to annoying banner notifications, to a continuation of the settings etc not saving unless you actually finish a game right through to the end first. The annoyances and bugs that interfere with the ability to actually finish a game with no glaring, in your face, bugs is getting less and less likely.This new UI is like the welcome mat for all players, new and old, that come to this product. It is time for FarSight to decide if they want to make a choice to aliente their entire customer base and continue on the path path of bad decisions, or merely make a few of them slightly diapointed and take the opportunity to fix things by slowing down their release schedule a bit. They have stated numerous times that their costs are so tight that they cannot take so much as a week off to spend time to fix things after it has been released, but if they don't this debacle may signify the end of TPA due to the erroneous decision to force an unfinished product out.Original Review:Get yer nostalgia on with true pinball tables re-created in The Pinball arcade. This is the best pinball simulator for the pinhead you know. Learn rulesets on real world machines for a fraction of the cost in arcades, and have access to some rare games that are difficult to find outside of museums, private collections or conventions.Be aware that even though this is listed under Free to Play you get a single tables free, but the rest of the tables are al a carte or you can buy season passes to buy in groups for a discounted rate.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Pinball is something I was never really interested in, as initially I thought it was just hitting a ball around a table hours on end trying to score points with no real object. I was very wrong and naive to think this as there is a lot to these table than meets the eyes. These pinball tables more specifically the newer ones with the dot matrix display tend to have a lot of missions and trick shots to complete in order to gain a larger amount of points in a quick succession. Though don't be fooled as completing these missions/ojectives are a lot harder than it seems. My favourite table at the moment is Monster Bash, it has a great theme, nice look and the sounds are really great, it has the arcade feel to it. The idea of the Monster Bash is to light every musician on the table to start the Monster Bash multiball. Lighting the musician's instrument requires completion of the mission/mode of that particular musician, e.g. completing Frankenstien's mode will light Frankenstien and his instrument the keyboard. Completing all the musicians and their instruments gives you a wizard mode called Monsters of Rock which is a multiball mode with higher jackpots than the Monster Bash multiball. You can find rulesheets online if you're unsure how each table is to be played. The game has a good replay value as you're always going back to try and improve on highscores and if you have friends who play it, more the reason to be competitive. If you're friends don't play this game you always have the Global Leaderboards to compete with. They are always updating the game with new tables which is good, the developers are active and are continually improving the game. The graphics seem fine, they could be cleaned up in some areas which I can see are improving on the DX11 version. The game has a nice solid feeling to it and does actually feel like a real pinball machine which offers that realism that makes it that more enjoyable. One thing is for sure mastering the technique of `tilting` is highly required if you're going for endurance and points. The good thing about this game is it allows you to trial everthing before you buy it, so I recommend the game as you can try it and if you don't like it, nothing is lost.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 14
												Has tons of great pinball tables, with more being added all the time. There's a ton of classic tables in here from Bally, Williams, Stern, as well as Gottlieb and other table manufacturers.The level of accuracy in each of these tables is really astounding, too. They scanned in the entire playing field, the backglass, the instructions near the front of the cabinet... they also render everything as it'd look on the actual table, not just on the playfield, but the tables all have accurate plungers and launch buttons.The ball physics in the game are also really well done, the ball feels like the proper weight that it would be in a real table, and it lends itself to the accuracy of the game. The physics do get a bit screwy sometimes, with the ball occasionally merging into other objects and not behaving like it should, however that happens so rarely that it's almost not even worth mentioning. For the most part the ball physics work as intended and feel great.The leaderboards really add something to the game, as well, especially if you have a friend that you're competing against, and the game makes this competition easy by having online "friend leaderboards".The online leaderboards also seem well managed, in the sense that the top scoring players appear to have gotten their scores legitmately and not through cheating.There's also challenges which have you go through a number of tables with only 3 credits to use on each one, where you try to reach a certain score on each table to allow you to progress. These challenges also have leaderboards, and it's all done using a balanced point system, meaning that a higher scoring table will get you a similar amount of points as a lower scoring table.This balanced point system is also used in tournaments, which are held occasionally and have their own rankign at the end of a certain time period.Overall, if you like pinball, this game delivers not only one of the most accurate pinball simulations I've seen, but also has a lot of features built into it to keep things fun and interesting. Would definitely recommend it to any pinball fans out there.
